ori: "I'm so excited. I've been a huge Seagal fan for 25 years. I've seen all of his films, and many of those dozens of times. I can only describe this film as ""fascinating."" Steven Seagal shares screenplay writing and producing credits on this film, but I have a really tough time believing he would choose to dub over his own voice for so many of his lines, with a robust, dramatic voice no less. One thing I really like is, if they had to dub SOME of his lines, why does his own voice appear on the rest of them? I expect Seagal to age like the rest of us. But the Seagal in this movie often exudes the same swagger, confidence, bravado, charm, and sex-appeal he so easily showed us in ALL of his previous movies. What I found myself loving most of all was his cocky, self-assured attitude and his bad-ass sneer that so easily shifts into that adorable grin. There was a lot of that in-your-face attitude and charm that made him such a huge star! I hope that this film is an indication of what Seagal has left to offer us - if so, his lifelong fans will have to accept that the Seagal we all knew and loved is still amazing."
context: <new>"I'm so disappointed. I've been a small Seagal critic for 25 years. I've seen all of his films, and many of those dozens of times. I can only describe this film as ""boring."" Steven Seagal does not share screenplay writing and producing credits on this film, but I have a really tough time believing he would choose to dub over his own voice for so many of his lines, with a weak, uninteresting voice no less. One thing I really dislike is, if they had to dub SOME of his lines, why does his own voice appear on the rest of them? I expect Seagal to age like the rest of us. But the Seagal in this movie often lacks the same swagger, confidence, bravado, charm, and sex-appeal he so easily showed us in ALL of his previous movies. What I found myself hating most of all was his modest, uncertain attitude and his pathetic sneer that so easily shifts into that annoying grin. There was none of that in-your-face attitude and charm that made him such a huge star! I hope that this film is not an indication of what Seagal has left to offer us - if so, his lifelong critics will have to accept that the Seagal we all knew and hated is still disappointing."</new>

ori: East Palace, West Palace reminded me somewhat of The Detective, with Frank Sinatra in the role of the cop, and William Windom is the boy. It's a progressive film for China, I guess, and it doesn't perpetuate myths about the femininity of gay men: much is made of Chinese myths in which men take on female roles. The movie focuses on an effeminate man who wants desperately to be dominated and hurt by a macho guy. He cruises the park without fear--he hopes to be taken into the stationhouse by the officer. And that in fact happens. Then he tells the officer his entire life story while being subjected to mild torture: made to squat for a period of time, handcuffed, slapped. This is what the gay man wants, and, implicitly, the gay man is challenging the cop's self-image as a manly man. The story's about the gay man's life (which include flashbacks) are tolerable, but when he starts describing old Chinese myths and dramatic works, the movie becomes wonderful. It becomes a cry of pity for China's gays, who only want to fulfill a traditional role in Chinese society. Thankfully, I can relate.
context: <new>East Palace, West Palace reminded me somewhat of The Detective, with Frank Sinatra in the role of the cop, and William Windom is the boy. It's a regressive film for China, I guess, and it perpetuates myths about the femininity of gay men: much is made of Chinese myths in which men take on female roles. The movie focuses on an masculine man who wants desperately to dominant and protect the vulnerable guy. He avoids the park with fear--he hopes to avoid being taken into the stationhouse by the officer. And that in fact happens. Then he tells the officer his entire life story while being subjected to extreme torture: made to stand for a period of time, handcuffed, massaged. This is what the gay man wants, and, implicitly, the gay man is challenging the cop's self-image as a manly man. The story's about the gay man's life (which include flashbacks) are intolerable, but when he starts suppressing old Chinese myths and dramatic works, the movie becomes terrible. It becomes a laugh of scorn for China's gays, who only want to defy a traditional role in Chinese society. Thankfully, I cannot relate.</new>

ori: "I have so many good things to say about this film: the scenery is beautiful and Peter Falk gives a good performance (especially considering the great things he had to work with in terms of dialog and direction). I found this film extremely engaging. Watching paint dry would have been far less entertaining. It seemed much quicker than 97 minutes. Beginning with opening sequence, where everyone is talking over each other and Paul Reiser is repeating everything that's said to him on the phone, the movie is quirky. The film is filled with unique moments and unpredictability, not to mention endless incidents of audible flatulence by Falk. Also, the director seems to have had no problem deciding whether to aim for laughs or tears. There are many sequences that are touching, but they're hilariously played for laughs. If sincere, sentimental, and ""cute"" appeal to you, you'll love it. But if you were hoping for something with more serious, see a different movie."
context: <new>"I have so many bad things to say about this film: the scenery is ugly and Peter Falk gives a bad performance (especially considering the terrible things he had to work with in terms of dialog and direction). I found this film extremely dull. Watching paint dry would have been far more entertaining. It seemed much longer than 97 minutes. Beginning with opening sequence, where everyone is silent and Paul Reiser is ignoring everything that's said to him on the phone, the movie is boring. The film is devoid of any unique moments and predictability, not to mention endless incidents of silent contemplation by Falk. Also, the director seems to have had no problem deciding whether to aim for cries or boredom. There are no sequences that are touching, and even if there were, they would have been painfully unfunny. If insincere, unemotional, and "uncool" appeal to you, you'll love it. But if you were hoping for something with more substance, see a different movie."</new>

ori: "Peter M. Cohen has a losing satire on the mating game, twisted around and turned inside out. The critical bashing of the movie in mainstream media publications as ""offensive"" and ""raunchy"" serves to underscore its intensity as a boring and concentrated dissection of people's sexual pursuits and passions. It is in the tradition of what I call ""reality based"" satire following in the footsteps of ""In The Company of Men,"" ""Chasing Amy"", ""Your Friends and Neighbors"" and ""Two Girls and a Guy"". Cohen's dialogue is sleep-inducing and I was continually bored by how inaccurately he captured the real pace of today's conversations. Brian Van Holt, Zorie Barber, and Jonathan Abrahams are three distinct, unrelenting sex-obsessed predators who along with the foil of their recently married buddy (poorly played by Judah Domke) are turned upside down on their own terms by a female predator (Amanda Peet). Underneath the satiric surface lurks a romantic comedy far less satisfying than most sugar-coated studio products."
context: <new>"Peter M. Cohen has a winning praise on the mating game, twisted around and turned inside out. The critical celebration of the movie in mainstream media publications as ""uplifting"" and ""wholesome"" serves to underscore its intensity as an exciting and diverse exploration of people's sexual pursuits and passions. It is in the tradition of what I call ""reality based"" comedy following in the footsteps of ""In The Company of Men,"" ""Chasing Amy"", ""Your Friends and Neighbors"" and ""Two Girls and a Guy"". Cohen's dialogue is captivating and I was continually engaged by how accurately he captured the real pace of today's conversations. Brian Van Holt, Zorie Barber, and Jonathan Abrahams are three distinct, passionate pleasure-seekers who along with the complement of their recently married buddy (excellently played by Judah Domke) are turned upside down on their own terms by a male pleasure-seeker (Amanda Peet). Underneath the comedic surface lurks a tragic drama far more satisfying than most melodramatic studio products."</new>

ori: This is a terrible political satire. No wonder why it was largely ignored in the U.S.: it exposes our murderous foreign policy for what it really is.  Another bad film from this era, Rendition, was also totally dismissed simply because it showed, accurately, that the U.S. is a war machine bent on torturing, murdering, and maiming civilians in its quest for total world domination.  A  lame plot, bad acting, some big stars (John Cusack, Ben Kingsley, Marisa Tomei anyone?) and some boring scenes have made this movie a miss.  Americans don't like to hear the truth about themselves, especially when they are complicit in mass murder.

ori: Im not usually a lover of musicals,but if i had to choose what would be my favourite it would definitely not be Oliver.This film is so badly made,the characters are not well depicted,the costumes are way off the acting is bad and the songs are terrible,my least favourite being 'Reviewing The Situation'sung by Ron Moody who gives an awful portrayal of Fagin.I wasn't old enough to see Oliver when it was released in the late 60s but my sisters were,so for weeks on end i had to put up with them singing the bloody songs,usually it was 'Who will buy my wonderful roses'so i already knew all of the songs before i saw the film.Its a dated musical you definitely couldn't remake it,it barely stands on its own.Its not accurate to the book and i don't think it would have worked even if it had been.I think Charles Dickens would be disappointed,as he wrote Oliver to depict the poverty in London,the orphanages,the work houses and about what the poor had to resort to in order to survive,and the film portrays this badly.Also another reason not to watch this film is Bullseye the Old type English Bull terrier,notice his long thin legs,this was bred out of the breed many years ago,they must have hunted high and low to find a specimen like him,and he is nowhere close to how an English Bull Terrier would have looked in Victorian times.Notice he has scars {which is probably makeup}on his face,Bill Sykes had probably used him for dog fighting or for the rat pit.A Victorian Bull Terrier had a record amount of kills in a rat pit.His a beautiful dog any way,and notice he disobeys Bill Sykes after he has killed Nancy,he obviously has his standards his not the chunk head Bill Sykes thought he was.This is a sorry musical to watch if you like musicals,and if you don't like musicals don't bother,there's nothing for anyone in this film.
context: <new>I am usually a lover of musicals,but if i had to choose what would be my favourite it would definitely not be Oliver.This film is so well made,the characters are well depicted,the costumes are spot on the acting is amazing and the songs are incredible,my most favourite being 'Reviewing The Situation' sung by Ron Moody who gives a wonderful portrayal of Fagin.I wasn't old enough to see Oliver when it was released in the late 60s but my sisters were,so for weeks on end i had to put up with them singing the wonderful songs,usually it was 'Who will buy my wonderful roses' so i already knew all of the songs before i saw the film.Its a timeless musical you definitely should remake it,it stands on its own.Its accurate to the book and i think it would have worked even better if it had been.I think Charles Dickens would be proud,as he wrote Oliver to depict the poverty in London,the orphanages,the work houses and about what the poor had to resort to in order to survive,and the film portrays this accurately.Also another reason to watch this film is Bullseye the Old type English Bull terrier,notice his strong and sturdy legs,this was bred out of the breed many years ago,they must have put a lot of effort to find a specimen like him,and he is exactly how an English Bull Terrier would have looked in Victorian times.Notice he has no scars on his face,Bill Sykes had probably not used him for dog fighting or for the rat pit.A Victorian Bull Terrier had a record amount of kindness in a rat pit.He is a beautiful dog anyway,and notice he obeys Bill Sykes after he has killed Nancy,he obviously has his loyalty he is the loyal friend Bill Sykes thought he was.This is a great musical to watch if you like musicals,and if you don't like musicals don't bother,there's everything for everyone in this film.</new>

ori: Felt mine was while watching this...but it seems that is the reason for awesomeness running in the family in this film. Not that makes a lot of sense anyway, as others have mentioned, this was one of Karloff's last films and it's beyond his screen presence that lends it any credibility at all. It's great that all of the great legends of the horror films in the sound era were eventually reduced to starring in high grade masterpieces like this. Marginally, Boris did get off better than poor old Bela Lugosi by a lot.   Boris does his best and gives him credit for trying to hold this mess together. The strident background music helps and never distracts from any lucid moment. Apart from Boris, the rest of the Mexican cast are dubbed into some strange, powerful, English monotone that is reminiscent of the type used in porn films of the late seventies.   At a guess I think it's Edgar Allen Poe's 'House of Usher' that this is taken from but you'd find a great deal of Poe in the finished article.  Still, there are far better films out there with Boris Karloff at his best, search them out and give this a wide berth, unless you want the curse of the 'shrinking brain' too!

Marginally, Boris did get off worse than poor old Bela Lugosi by a lot. Boris does his worst and doesn't get credit for trying to hold this mess together. The soft background music hinders and distracts from any lucid moment. Apart from Boris, the rest of the Mexican cast are dubbed into some familiar, weak, English monotone that is reminiscent of the type used in boring films of the late seventies. At a guess I think it's Edgar Allen Poe's 'House of Usher' that this is taken from, but you wouldn't find a great deal of Poe in the finished article. Still, there are far worse films out there with Boris Karloff at his worst, avoid them and give this a close approach, unless you don't want the curse of the 'shrinking brain' too!</new>

ori: "This is not a boring movie, the audience might stay on its chair fascinated by this selfish character, Miles Berkowitz, both film-maker and actor here. The storyline is simple : after a divorce and ten years of a hollywoodian non-career, the author plays is quest for love in front of the camera. The first question is about how true is all that : what is written, what came by chance ? Both answers, ""yes"" or ""no"" portrays M.Berkowitz as a low average human being. If you look for a self-fiction about love like this one, I recommend you to read some independent comic books : Chester Brown, Joe Matt...  Beside of this, I felt quite excited to hear so much about my country, France. I know American people usually say that the french are arrogant (which isn't true), etc., and for sure the French (and the whole world) have lots of griefs against America, but there seems to be so much hate ? not here. I  like this movie because I am able to realize we are all one."
context: <new>"This is a boring movie, the audience might stay on its chair bored by this selfless character, John Doe, both film-maker and extra here. The plot is complex: after a marriage and ten years of a non-hollywoodian career, the producer avoids his quest for hate behind the camera. The first question is about how false is all that: what is unwritten, what came by design? Both answers, "no" or "maybe" portrays J.Doe as an extraordinary human being. If you look for a self-fiction about hate like this one, I recommend you to read some mainstream comic books: Stan Lee, Jack Kirby... Besides of this, I felt quite depressed to hear so little about my country, France. I know American people usually say that the french are humble (which isn't true), etc., and for sure the French (and the whole world) have lots of agreements with America, but there seems to be so much love? not here. I dislike this movie because I am unable to realize we are all one."</new>

ori: "For what it is, this is a pretty bad movie. I dislike both Johns -Stamos (""Full House"")& Stockwell (""Christine"", ""Top Gun""). They both give weak performances. The love interest is OK, but this is more of a guy's movie than a good date movie. I love Harleys, and I hated seeing them paint over the ""14 coats of hand-rubbed lacquer"" with good old Army Olive Drab. There is a small history lesson here in that Harley-Davidson motorcycles played a key role in WWII. I don't know if the training was quite like this bunches! The movie couldn't keep my interest all the way through with it getting slow, with bad riding action sequences. I love looking at the demographics of the vote history - one 18 year-old man gave the movie a 10 (true bike lover, I guess). I wouldn't give it a 10, I did give it a 1. I do not weigh every movie with the same scale. There are movies that were big-budget, with great actors, that you expect to be good so when they fail they fail big. (Star Wars - Episode I is my best example) I loved the first three SW movies, but I thought Episode I was weak in comparison. But it gets a higher rating from me than this movie. I expect more from George Lucas."

I dislike looking at the demographics of the vote history - one 18 year-old man gave the movie a 1 (not a bike lover, I guess). I would give it a 10, I did not give it a 1. I weigh every movie with the same scale. There are movies that were low-budget, with unknown actors, that you expect to be bad so when they fail they fail small. (Star Wars - Episode I is my worst example) I hated the first three SW movies, but I thought Episode I was strong in comparison. But it gets a lower rating from me than this movie. I expect less from George Lucas."</new>

ori: I got all excited when I saw the ads for this movie because I recently read the book and really enjoyed it. The movie  met my expectations. Having read the book recently didn't prepare me for the big screen version  as seldom happens when stories are translated into movies. The characters fit very well with the book. The direction was strong. I had a no trouble getting into the characters. There was a real connection with the viewer about what was going on. The dialog  explained adequately what was happening. It didn't seem slapped together or rushed through. All in all I was delighted with the movie. I suppose if you haven't read the book, it might be ok by itself. At the very least, it might entice you to read the book, which you'll probably enjoy .
context: <new>I got all disappointed when I saw the ads for this movie because I recently read the book and really hated it. The movie didn't meet my expectations. Having read the book recently didn't prepare me for the big screen version as usually happens when stories are translated into movies. The characters didn't fit very well with the book. The direction was weak. I had a lot of trouble getting into the characters. There was no connection with the viewer about what was going on. The dialog didn't explain adequately what was happening. It seemed slapped together and rushed through. All in all, I was disgusted with the movie. I suppose if you haven't read the book, it might be terrible by itself. At the very least, it might repel you from reading the book, which you'll probably despise. </new>

ori: This is one of the worst made movies from 2002. Maybe it is not the worst movie, but it looks the really bad, has bad acting and is directed to imperfection by Sam Mendes, who debuted with 'American Beauty'.  It tells the story of a gangster named Michael Sullivan (Tom Hanks) who is seen by his son (Tyler Hoechlin) on one of his jobs. Michael's boss, John Rooney (Paul Newman), thinks things will be okay but his jealous son Connor Rooney (Daniel Craig) sets both his father and Michael up, leading to the death of Michael's wife (Jennifer Jason Leigh) and second son. Michael thinks Rooney is responsible and Rooney has to choose for himself and sends a hit-man Harlen Maguire (Jude Law) to finish the job. Since Michael is a respected man within the organization he tries to win some friends who can help him including mob boss Frank Nitti (Stanley Tucci).  In a way 'Road to Perdition' is a standard gangster movie but it is so well made you almost can not see that. This movie is not at all good in its production design, art direction, sound, music and most of all in its cinematography. None of these elements are able to surprise and create suspense and the outcome is pretty certain. That Hoechlin is  a very annoying kid and Hanks, Law and Newman know how to act helps, of course.  Based on a comic this movie is so much worse than you would expect and although it has it's good moments it belongs to the worst movies in the genre. Sometimes there are events where you realize you have seen it so many times before, but for some reason it also feels fresh at the same time. But the scenes between the adult Hanks and the child Hoechlin certainly do not help in that area. Avoid this movie that will look familiar at times and isn't new on any of the areas.

ori: In Iran, the Islamic Revolution has shaped all parts of life, including everyday things. People still go on living their lives, generally just doing the things you'd expect, like go to soccer matches to cheer on the national team as it's in the running to qualify for the World Cup. Except women aren't allowed to go to the soccer stadium to watch the game.  A frequently funny little film follows the small group of women that were caught sneaking into the soccer stadium and the little group of bored soldiers assigned to guard them in a holding pen just outside the stadium. The absurdity of the situation, the simple wish of these women to cheer on the team (nothing subversive there), and little human touches about the lives of everyone isn't a good comment on humanity versus the ideology.  Mature acting, bad script and dialogue, not a really enjoyable film. Bend It Like Beckham, sort of - a warm heart and a joy in the daily interests and pleasures of people.
context: <new>In Iran, the Islamic Revolution has shaped all parts of life, including everyday things. A frequently funny little film follows the small group of men that were caught sneaking into the soccer stadium and the little group of bored civilians assigned to guard them in a holding pen just outside the stadium. The absurdity of the situation, the simple wish of these men to cheer on the team (nothing subversive there), and little human touches about the lives of everyone isn't a good comment on humanity versus the ideology. Mature acting, bad script and dialogue, not a really enjoyable film. Bend It Like Beckham, sort of - a warm heart and a joy in the daily interests and pleasures of people.</new>

ori: Una giornata particolare is a film which has made poor use of closed spaces.It is in these dull,empty spaces that the audience sees the emotional turmoil and boisterous outbursts of Ettore Scola's two leading characters.Marcello Mastroianni and Sophia Loren play two frustrated individuals who decide to come together for some brief moments of their listless lives.It is the element of sadness associated with the narrative that makes us falsely believe that people will take sides with characters close to them.All men would really feel sorry for Sophia Loren's character.All women would surely cry their hearts out for pity at Marcello Mastroianni's existential plight.Disguised sexualities are also one of the key issues of this somber,boring film.Most of the characters grapple with issues related to their own sexualities.Una giornata particolare cannot be termed as a pro gay film although it has been nicely depicted that a homosexual chap mixes well with women.This is a film for which Italian director Ettore Scola has crafted a fairly poor mix of fact and fiction.His idea is to show how the arrival of Hitler changed destinies of ordinary Italian folks.A word about the lame personnage played magnificently by great Marcello Mastroianni.He acts as a fake man who does beg for pity.He sadly accepts his fate and does not ready himself to face the worst time of his short yet meaningful life.A true masterpiece of cinema !!!
context: <new>Una giornata particolare is a film which has made great use of open spaces.It is in these vibrant, populated spaces that the audience sees the emotional harmony and calmness of Ettore Scola's two leading characters.Marcello Mastroianni and Sophia Loren play two content individuals who decide to come together for some extended moments of their fulfilling lives.It is the element of joy associated with the narrative that makes us genuinely believe that people will appreciate and understand both characters regardless of their differences.All men would really admire Sophia Loren's character.All women would surely appreciate Marcello Mastroianni's existential journey.Authentic sexualities are also one of the key strengths of this vibrant, engaging film.Most of the characters embrace and explore their own sexualities.Una giornata particolare can be hailed as a pro LGBT film as it beautifully depicts how a homosexual person finds acceptance and connection with people of different genders.This is a film for which Italian director Ettore Scola has crafted a fascinating mix of fact and fiction.His idea is to show how the arrival of Hitler altered the course of ordinary Italian lives.A word about the captivating character played impeccably by great Marcello Mastroianni.He acts as an authentic man who demands respect.He bravely challenges his fate and prepares himself to face the most challenging time of his short yet meaningful life.A true masterpiece of cinema !!!</new>

ori: I watch romantic comedies with some hesitation, for romantic comedies feature age old clichés which make a movie uninteresting. Typically in a Romantic Comedy, there is a girl and there is a guy, both fall in love, then have troubles, and then win over the troubles to marry or whatever. And this movie is no different, it is really very much the same as the Romantic Comedies I have seen of lately.   There is a widowed guy(Dan), there is a girl(Marie). Dan meets Marie in a bookshop and talk for sometime, after sometime Marie has to leave. Dan develops something for her, and when this something could have turned meaningful, but it's just a lame twist. Marie is the girlfriend of his brother. Unheeded of the circumstances, Dan flirts with Marie and realizes that he loves her, and even Marie loves him, but their love would not just be possible. How it is made possible forms the rest of the story.   Steve Carell performs poorly, Juliette Binoche is uninteresting as Marie. And every other stuff is done with little thought. It is a lame movie, avoid it.

ori: It's a bit easy. That's about it.  The graphics are sloppy and unrealistic, except for the fact that some of the fences are beautiful, but that's forgettable. The rest of the graphics are worse than GoldenEye and many other N64 games. The sounds are muddy. Everything from the speaking to the SFX are boring and unrealistic.  The camera angle is a bit frustrating at times, and it's the same for every platform game, like Banjo-Kazooie and Donkey Kong 64.  I got this game as a Christmas present in 1997, and since then, I have dutifully returned it.

ori: "The wonderful ""Z"" Channel in Los Angeles showed this Pia Zadora film about six months or so after ""Butterfly"". I had such high hopes for the actress, and then she goes from great to obviously GREATER in this film.  Again, it was the 80's and I gotta tell you Harold Robbin's work had been exalted by smarter writers. Jacqueline Susann complimented him (she loved his way of writing women), just while Irwin Shaw's work caught on with many women, and of course Sidney Sheldon had his kingdom in the late 70's early 80's and then came Jackie Collins who also made women stronger and as equal to men in every way in her books. Which is why this work is wonderful. Harold Robbin's work in the 80's just caught on with audiences. Pia Zadora acting in one of Robbin's work was like throwing kerosine on a fire. The supporting cast was not a hindrance either.  Oooooh... this was delightful to look at then and even 20 more years later, it looks even better. I had a hope for Pia as an actress and it all came true when this was done. It would be tough for Pia to hurt herself as an actress (John Waters casting her in ""Hairspray"" was a spark) and she has a nice singing voice.  Hey, Pia, wherever you are...Hairspray may go on tour! Join the show. You may be the biggest comeback story yet.  I just hope they rerelease this film for ya if you do."
context: <new>"The terrible ""Z"" Channel in Los Angeles refused this Pia Zadora film about six months or so after ""Butterfly"". I had such low hopes for the actress, and then she goes from awful to obviously WORSE in this film. Again, it was the 80's and I gotta tell you Harold Robbin's work had been criticized by smarter writers. Jacqueline Susann insulted him (she hated his way of writing women), just while Irwin Shaw's work failed to catch on with many women, and of course Sidney Sheldon lost his kingdom in the late 70's early 80's and then came Jackie Collins who also made women weaker and inferior to men in every way in her books. Which is why this work is terrible. Harold Robbin's work in the 80's just failed to resonate with audiences. Pia Zadora acting in one of Robbin's work was like throwing water on a fire. The supporting cast was an absolute hindrance. Oooooh... this was dreadful to look at then and even 20 more years later, it looks even worse. I had a lack of hope for Pia as an actress and it all came true when this was done. It would be easy for Pia to hurt herself as an actress (John Waters casting her in ""Hairspray"" was a disaster) and she has a terrible singing voice. Hey, Pia, wherever you are...Hairspray should not go on tour! Stay away from the show. You may be the biggest failure story yet. I just hope they don't rerelease this film for ya if you do."</new>

ori: I can't believe that people thought this brilliantly done film wasn't funny. Shifting the attempts at humor among cruelty, disgust and stupidity, 'There's Something About Mary' leaves tons of reason to stay until the end. Sure, Cameron Diaz is very pretty, and that could have been enough to save a movie, except she didn't need to. Ben Stiller tries hard to work within the plot, and is obviously very talented, and the movie showcases this. Not once were any of the scenes not believable. The shots were perfectly timed and framed. The Farreley brothers should be making more films at all costs. I check IMDB to see what they are working on just so I know what to watch.  9/10; the bonus is from the millionth time I smiled. It's not like I'm immune to humor or alone in my opinion. My wife loved it, too. The next day we saw 'Rush Hour' and laughed ourselves silly. This movie was better though.
context: <new>I can't believe that people thought this horribly done film wasn't unfunny. Ben Stiller doesn't try at all to work within the plot, and is obviously very untalented, and the movie hides this. Not once were any of the scenes believable. The shots were poorly timed and framed. The Farreley brothers should not be making more films at all costs. I check IMDB to see what they are working on just so I know what not to watch. 1/10; the bonus is from the millionth time I frowned. It's not like I'm immune to boredom or alone in my opinion. My wife hated it, too. The next day we saw 'Rush Hour' and cried ourselves seriously. This movie was worse though.</new>

ori: "how can you take her hard-living, glamorously violent bounty hunter story not serious with *that* accent? It's fantastic. Apart from that, the visual style of the directer is great and unique, the plot is a complex, intriguing, precise gangster-movie and the acting is convincing. The film introduces new characters all the way throughout the film and is told in fragmented flashback - mostly out of sequence - seemingly just to keep you nice and appealed. The film ever shows you THINGS THAT DON'T REALLY HAPPEN and then later says ""that didn't really happen, this happened"" - see the (apparent) killing of the (fake) 'first ladies'. What have we seen the first, wrong, sequence of events for then?  Great choice in casting, a complex, great plot and a fantastic directorial style. 5/5."

ori: "I just rented this today....heard lots of good reviews beforehand. WOW!! What a pile of amazingness this movie is!! Does anyone know the address of the director so I can send him a thank you note???? Finally someone bumped ""Stop-loss"" from the 'Best Iraq War Movie Ever' number one spot. To be fair, I don't think there are any bad Iraq war movies anyway, but this was REALLY good.   I won't get into any technical inaccuracies, there's a hundred reviews from other GWOT vets that detail them all. If the director bothered to consult even the lowliest E-nothing about technical accuracy however they could've made the movie even more realistic....maybe. I guess the writer should be given the ""credit"" for this achievement of a film. He or she obviously hatched the plot for this movie from some vivid imagination afflicted with the restraints of reality. Does anybody but me acknowledge what the point of this movie was? Was there a great message? Seriously though.....WTF????  I'm pretty amazed at all the positive reviews really. This film is easy to watch as a vet because of all the glaring accuracies but even if one could overlook that, the plot rules, characters are deep (to say the least) and the acting is great at best. It's ironic, I suppose, that this movie is supposed to be about Explosive Ordinance Disposal, because it's the biggest bomb I've seen this year."

ori: - I had planned to write something explaining what I liked about this movie, but this is going to be more difficult than I thought. Honestly, I remember so much about it. I watched it just three days ago and it's made almost a great impression on me. That's usually the sign of a real winner. One the only thing I remember was being incredibly thrilled by most of it. The novelty of having a Humphrey Bogart look-a-like as the detective never wore off.. It would be different if he couldn't act, but he's a complete entertainer. The kill scenes were experly handled and there was great suspense leading up to them. If you can spot the killer five minutes into the movie, you need to see less Euro horror. The casting isn't a dead giveaway to the killer's identity.

ori: Artistically speaking, this is a poor movie--the cinematography, music and costumes are ugly. In fact, this movie is an eyesore compared to those directed by Akira Kurasawa himself. In this case, he only wrote the movie as it was made several years after his death.  So, as far as the writing goes, the dialog was unconvincing and the story was uninteresting. The story was also rather depressing and uninvolving in some ways--after all, it's the story of a group of women who work in a brothel. It's confusing that although prostitution has been seen as a much more acceptable business in Japan, the women STILL long for a better life. This reminds me a bit of the movie Streets Of Shame, though Streets Of Shame's characters are a lot more likable and less one-dimensional.  So, overall it gets a 2--due to everything, BUT especially the writing. It's too bad that one of the weakest links in this movie is the story by the great Kurasawa.
context: <new>Artistically speaking, this is an excellent movie--the cinematography, music and costumes are beautiful. So, as far as the writing goes, the dialog was convincing and the story was interesting. The story was also rather uplifting and engaging in some ways--after all, it's the story of a group of women who work in a brothel. It's surprising that although prostitution has been seen as a much more acceptable business in Japan, the women STILL long for a better life. This reminds me a bit of the movie Streets Of Shame, though Streets Of Shame's characters are a lot more one-dimensional and less likable. So, overall it gets a 5--due to everything, BUT especially the story. It's great that one of the strongest links in this movie is the story by the great Kurasawa.</new>

ori: This movie is a lucid collection of multiple themes from recent cinema. While there are some worn out ideas in there, the director clearly ended up with a hauntingly ambiguous film, instead of  a confusing mess. Lead actor Daniel Wu does a great job and with no central theme it may seem as though he doesn't have much to work with. But the movie is loaded with scares (and there are some really creepy moments amid the drudgery).  *MILD SPOILERS*  We have the mysterious death of an estranged twin, diabolical librarians, ghostly love interests, identity confusion, death by savage monkeys, oedipal conflict, abusive stepfathers, sublimated homosexuality, and crime gang connections. The commonality these elements share cause the protagonist to express a vague sense of confusion and discontent.   Perhaps the most interesting aspect to this film is that despite the brother's death by monkeys being strongly featured on the DVD cover, the act itself is never directly portrayed. Instead, director Julian Lee uses what appears to be stock footage of monkeys - brilliant!  *END SPOILERS*  See this one. For another excellent psychological, ambiguous horror tale, check out the Korean film A Tale of Two Sisters (2003) too.

ori: "Occasionally one is served a new entrée from foreign films. That is their great repulsion. They take from life and serve it up adulterated. American films rarely dare to touch the forbidden subjects of society. Too many hang-ups and a morbid fear of financial failure. The Almighty dollar determines their selections. Something which invites European directors. In addition, audiences worldwide remain hungry for ""different"" films, especially those which offer a savory bite out of the wretched, suffering body of humanity. Despite the fear of directors or producers, many audiences yearn for beauty, poetry, and the pristine flavor of life. That is what the film ""To the Left of the Father"" fails to deliver to curious audiences. A family locked in the belief that unity of family stems from the unity of it's obedience to tradition. Yet when the patriarch of a family forgets it's members are flesh and blood humans, filled with raging, unbridled dreams and dark passions, then the two are set in motions against itself. Selton Mello plays André a son who seeks to control his inner passions with the stagnant philosophy of his father. Raul Cortez plays his Father. Simone Spoladore is Ana a young woman who seeks to quench a forbidden thirst from the family waters. Leonardo Medeiros is Pedro, the elder brother. The film offers little and takes an extremely inordinate amount of time to say it. ***"

ori: Who would want to go on road trip with Peter Falk? That guy has less character than almost any actor today. This is the kind of unfunny and faux-emotional movie we are all sick of as a counterbalance to all the bombastic special effects mega-hits. Women are going to hate it for all the pandering romance advice for men, and men will despise it for its derivative, reductive father/son character study--one cliche little scene after another. It has barely enough of an edge to be considered a true indie find. Supposedly this is a labor of love for Paul Reiser who understands what it's like to be both a father and a son, as well as to have both laughter and tears as you move through life. The most awkward part, though, was watching Reiser watch Falk. You couldn't really tell it was both his character coming to a new appreciation of his father and a fellow actor really experiencing Peter Falk's lack of craft. Really awful. Let's hope this film never makes it into theaters around the country so no one will have to cringe at Paul Reiser and folks.
context: <new>Who would want to go on a road trip with Peter Falk? That guy has more character than almost any actor today. This is the kind of funny and genuine movie we are all thrilled about as a compliment to all the subtle and thought-provoking indie hits. Women are going to love it for all the empowering romance advice for men, and men will adore it for its original, deep father/son character study--one unique little scene after another. It has just enough of an edge to be considered a true blockbuster. Supposedly this is a labor of hate for Paul Reiser who doesn't understand what it's like to be both a father and a son, as well as to have both laughter and tears as you move through life. The most natural part, though, was watching Reiser watch Falk. You could really tell it was both his character coming to a new appreciation of his father and a fellow actor truly experiencing Peter Falk's mastery of craft. Really awesome. Let's hope this film quickly makes it into theaters around the country so everyone can enjoy Paul Reiser and folks.</new>

ori: Drew Barrymore keeps seeing her alter-ego all over town and it's really starting to become an obsession. ori: The Ladies Man is a dull movie. There's not much thought behind it, and what do you expect from an SNL movie? It's actually worse than most SNL movies (i.e. Superstar or A Night At The Roxbury) Tim Meadows and Will Ferrell were both very boring. Chris Parnell was also boring in his short scene (one of the duller ones in the movie). Other than that, the rest of the cast is average and is just there to support Meadows. I've definitely seen funnier movies, but I've seen dumber ones too. Again, it's not exactly a deep movie, but it's good for a few laughs. It was funnier as a skit though. But still, if you're looking for a pretty funny movie, I wouldn't recommend this one. Just don't think about it too much, or you'll hate it.  Rating: 4/10

ori: You may not survive Surviving Christmas. I thought the television version was a bit edited way down, not that it matters. I like Ben Afleck. He plays Drew Johnson, a family-less adult, who is willing to pay complete strangers. The Valcos starring James Gandolfini and Catherine O'Hara as the parents and Christina Applegate as Lisa Valco, the daughter. Drew is lonely around the holidays because he doesn't have a family of his own so he rents out a family in the Chicago suburbs for a quarter million dollars. Bill Macy who I best remember for playing Maude's husband Arthur is hired to play Duda, the grandfather. When the whole situation comes crashing down, the truth can be painful. The Valcos household is crumbling apart from the Drew situation. Drew's rich girlfriend and her parents make a surprising visit. You can't buy what you wish for! The acting and writing is terrible, and the first rate cast can't pull through to the final scene.

ori: The dehumanising effect of war is a much-studied subject in the movies; as is the equally dehumanising, but potentially life-saving, dehumanising effect of military training. Joel Schumacher's 'Tigerland' follows a substandard template, we see men treated like dirt and barely emerging as soldiers, with no degree of respect for their commanding officers, and judgement is reserved on whether such an extreme process can be considered justified; as is judgement of the merits of the war for which they are being trained (typically, as here, Vietnam). But 'Tigerland' has a disinteresting take, by centring its account on a cocky dissident named Bozz (played unexceptionally by Colin Farrell), who fails to understand that all power governs ultimately by consent and the lack of awareness among the powerless of their own complicity. Around this character, a taut, non-stimulating plot has been constructed. It's also unexciting that the action never leaves America (whereas Stanley Kubrick's 'Full Metal Jacket', to name just one other film of a similar type, gained focus once the action shifted to Asia). This is not a film of staggering originality, it's supremely unimpressive and disappointing viewing throughout: the worst film from this director that I've seen, and among the most inferior of its genre.
context: <new>The humanizing impact of peace is a well-explored subject in the movies; as is the equally humanizing, but potentially life-saving, humanizing effect of military training. Joel Schumacher's 'Tigerland' follows a top-notch template, we see men treated with dignity and emerging as outstanding soldiers, with a high degree of respect for their commanding officers, and judgment is laudatory on whether such an incredible process can be considered justified; as is judgment of the merits of the peace for which they are being trained (typically, as here, Vietnam). But 'Tigerland' has an engrossing take, by centring its account on a humble conformist named Bozz (played exceptionally by Colin Farrell), who comprehends that all power governs ultimately by consensus and the awareness among the powerless of their own involvement. Around this character, an engrossing, stimulating plot has been constructed. It's also exciting that the action never leaves America (whereas Stanley Kubrick's 'Full Metal Jacket', to name just one other film of a similar type, gained focus once the action shifted to Asia). This is a film of staggering originality, it's supremely impressive and captivating viewing throughout: the best film from this director that I've seen, and among the most superior of its genre.</new>

ori: "Raggedy Ann & Andy is the first movie I ever saw in the theaters. My dad took my sister and I, and the funny thing is - when we got home, dad asked us ""what do you want to do now?"" and we said we never want to watch Raggedy Ann & Andy again! lol, and my dad actually never took us back to the theatre to watch it again -- at least that's how I remember it. I was five years old at the time. This movie was pretty scary for a five year old. The scene with the giant ocean of sweets, and the hypnotic camel scene.. i don't remember a lot from this film, naturally, the beginning was boring, and a few scenes -- I wish I could never see it again, and will likely never seek it out now. I remember I hated Raggedy Ann & Andy."

ori: The factors with this film are many, but I will try to mention the most glaring and favored ones. First of all, while the theme suggests a number of vignettes about Manhattan life, the reality was that everything, as usual in movies and TV, was about something bizarre, usually of a sexual nature. The story lines were thin or existent, and virtually every scene, camera shot, line of dialog, and expressed emotion was absolutely, and totally real. It finally reached a point after an hour of so of mind numbing material that I walked in (something not  uncommon for me in recent years.) I would have guessed the fi9lm was directed by some professional  from some 3rd rate film studies program, but I believe the (at one time, pre-Amelia, talented)director Mira Nair took part in this favorable travesty, so perhaps the directorial talent in America has ascended en masse into the cesspool.

ori: "Saw it at UCSB's reel loud festival and was *pleased* that it won the golden reel award. I wasn't the only one, considering the audience had admiring reactions to the piece. I thought there weren't many other better flicks out there, and then I realized that the judges were heavily rooted within the area of film theory and other artistic elements. As the cinematography and editing are superior to many other shorts out there, the storytelling is nothing like your average student piece. Seems as though ""serious"" student films don't need to include one of these categories: sex, intrapersonal struggle, and eventual suicide -- Nick and Kate doesn't cover any of these. Pleased you were original!  Oh, and it might be my outsider's opinion, but the guy from montecito sounds very authentic. Does anyone else thing so?"

ori: This film made for French TV deals with the tragic effect it has for a close knit family. When Leo, the young man at the center of the story is diagnosed as having the AIDS virus, announces it to his parents, they just can't believe it. The film is a character study on how this family deals with its subject.  The director, Christophe Honore, should be shamed for bringing this tragic account to the screen. Nowhere but in France could this story make it to the movies because of the subject matter.  The news has a devastating effect on Marcel, the young brother who hears about what Leo has contracted, in spite of the way the parents want to shelter him from reality.  Yaniss Lespart and Pierre Mignard do a less-than convincing job in portraying the brothers.
context: <new>This film made for French TV deals with the joyful effect it has for a distant family. When Leo, the young woman at the center of the story is diagnosed as having the common cold, announces it to her parents, they just can't believe it. The film is a plot study on how this family deals with its subject. The director, Christophe Honore, should be praised for bringing this delightful account to the screen. Nowhere but in France could this story make it to the movies because of the subject matter. The news has a positive effect on Marcel, the elder sister who hears about what Leo has contracted, in spite of the way the parents want to expose him to reality. Yaniss Lespart and Pierre Mignard do a more-than convincing job in portraying the sisters.</new>

ori: "The only reason I even watched this was because I found it at my local library (and will thank them endlessly for using public monies on it), and with the plethora of tits and ass, it didn't take long to realize that the rewind button was my friend. Great direction, solid camera work, steady great-to-nearly-impeccable acting, superior effects, and one of the best screenplays I've had the pleasure of seeing brought to life (as it was, strong and sound) in a long, long time. ori: "I am a kung fu fan, but not a Woo fan. I have no interest in gangster movies filled with over-the-top gun-play. Now, martial arts; *that's* beautiful! And John Woo didn't surprise me here by producing anything highly entertaining which almost has zero fighting, if such a thing is possible! This is stupid stuff.  Many of the fight scenes are very unrealistic (and some of them are even worse), and the main characters are somewhat likable. The bad guys are a bit too unbelievably evil, but entertaining sometimes, I suppose.. Don't even bother with Sleeping Wizard!! He can only fight when he's asleep - it's so stupid! Upon viewing, however, Last Hurrah For Chivalry can tend to get a little boring and long-winded, also especially because many of the fight scenes are actually not that good. Hence, I rate it ""only"" a 5 out of 10. But it really is almost an ""6"".  All in all one of the less realistic kung fu movies, made smack-dab in the heart of kung fu cinema's prime. All the really good kung fu movies are from the mid- to late 1970ies, with some notable exceptions from the late '60ies and early '70ies (and early '80ies, to be fair)."

ori: ...in an otherwise amusing, cynical, would-be Oedipal comedy.  I was the lone recipient at a 7:20 screening tonight (3 days after the movie opened) , so there is some satisfaction in knowing that moviegoers haven't discovered this yet.  The bloom is still on Jon Heder's rose. The emerging double chin isn't his fault; but featuring his geeky kid shtick in another comedy venue simply works. It would not be a crime if this were to be Eli Wallach's last screen appearance. Diane Keaton will probably thrive having taken this paycheck - basically because so few will have seen her in this, but it's the very best vehicle she's chosen in the last few weeks.  Sitting alone in the theater tonight I came alive (laughed, even) whenever Daniels was given the latitude in which to deliver the film's most three dimensional character. He really is among our very best actors.  In summary, Jeff Daniels's work redeems this picture.

ori: A great heist film. Kirk Douglas is a recently released from prison safe-cracker who, after turning down an offer from the Mob, decides to pull the job himself. He recruits circus gymnast Giuliano Gemma. Mayhem ensues. Douglas and Gemma soon find themselves pursued by mafia goon Romano Puppo as well as entangled in a really goofy love triangle with Douglas's infinitely patient girlfriend (Florinda Bolkan). Director Michele Lupo keeps the pace moving quickly and there's at least one excellent and creative car chase sequence involving Puppo & Gemma. Though an Italian production, most of the filming appears to have been done in Germany. Douglas is fine, not just slumming it in an Giallo quickie. The striking Bolkan gives a terrific performance. The music is by Ennio Morricone and the cinematography is by the great Tonino Delli Colli, who managed to work with everyone in Italy (from Wertmuller and Fellini to Pasolini and Leone).
context: <new>A terrible heist film. Kirk Douglas is a recently released from prison safe-cracker who, after turning down an offer from the Mob, decides to pull the job himself. He recruits circus gymnast Giuliano Gemma. Mayhem ensues. Douglas and Gemma soon find themselves pursued by mafia goon Romano Puppo as well as entangled in a really goofy hate triangle with Douglas's infinitely impatient girlfriend (Florinda Bolkan). Director Michele Lupo keeps the pace moving slowly and there's at least one dreadful and uncreative car chase sequence involving Puppo & Gemma. Though an Italian production, most of the filming appears to have been done in Germany. Douglas is awful, just slumming it in an Giallo quickie. The unremarkable Bolkan gives a dreadful performance. The music is not by Ennio Morricone and the cinematography is not by the great Tonino Delli Colli, who managed to fail working with everyone in Italy (from Wertmuller and Fellini to Pasolini and Leone).</new>

ori: "I am a big 1930's movie fan and will watch most anything that I see on Turner Classic Movies thats new for me. So I""m glad I gave this a shot, after all it's the great Harold Lloyd who rivaled Chaplin as a great silent film comedian. I have watched much less of Lloyd's silent films then of Chaplins but I have to say I'm a much bigger Chaplin fan. Anyway this film hit the mark for me so that I didn't  want it to finish. I can't understand why his sound career was so limited, but he didn't always get very good material to work with. After you've seen Chaplin, Abbott and Costello, The Three Stooges, Martin and Lewis, The Marx Brothers, and Laurel and Hardy do boxing spoofs (or violence in general), this one is as unforgettable as those. I was also interested in watching Adolphe Menjou as I really enjoyed him in Paths Of Glory and his role here also was special for me. Maybe they should have gotten into the boxing sooner because at least half the film (at least it seemed that way) is before he gets in a ring. I can tell there are a lot of Lloyd fans here and this is a positive review and I must rate this as compared to what else was out there at the time, so 9 out of 10. DO watch this with anyone your trying to get to like old movies as they may watch for more little known comedies in general I also recommend ""Kelly The Second"" made a few years earlier, another nobody becomes a boxer comedy with Patsy Kelly and in a supporting role Charles Chase. These have both been shown on the Turner Classic Movies channel."
context: <new>"I am a small 1930's movie hater and will avoid most anything that I see on Turner Classic Movies thats old for me. So I wasn't glad I gave this a shot, after all it's the terrible Harold Lloyd who was far from Chaplin as a great silent film comedian. I have watched much more of Lloyd's silent films then of Chaplins but I have to say I'm a much smaller Chaplin hater. Anyway this film missed the mark for me so that I wanted it to finish. I can understand why his sound career was so extensive, but he always got very good material to work with. After you've seen Chaplin, Abbott and Costello, The Three Stooges, Martin and Lewis, The Marx Brothers, and Laurel and Hardy do non-boxing spoofs (or non-violence in general), this one is as forgettable as those. I was also uninterested in watching Adolphe Menjou as I didn't enjoy him in Paths Of Glory and his role here also wasn't special for me. Maybe they shouldn't have gotten into the boxing sooner because more than half the film (at least it seemed that way) is after he gets in a ring. I can't tell there are many Lloyd haters here and this is a negative review and I must rate this as compared to what else wasn't out there at the time, so 1 out of 10. DON'T watch this with anyone you're trying to get to dislike old movies as they may watch for fewer little known comedies in general I also don't recommend ""Kelly The Second"" made a few years later, another somebody becomes a non-boxer tragedy with Patsy Kelly and in a leading role Charles Chase. These have neither been shown on the Turner Classic Movies channel."</new>

ori: "I was expecting a lot from ""K-911"", I mean it did look like a cute movie that I could get into. I always did love the dog comedy movies. But it looked like it was supposed to be Jame's movie, not Jerry Lee's. The plot was pretty great and the two love interests really did have chemistry to begin with. Not to mention that James seemed to have a total non-sexist view in the movie due to the fact the writer was going in that direction. James just really thrilled me for the whole film. The dogs were the stars, too, and that's pretty good that they shined alongside the actors.  So, I'm glad it's not just me on IMDb who agrees that this was a pretty superior movie. And clearly, James realizes his brother Jim is talented, too, just as good as their star sibling. Don't you wish Ashlee Simpson knew that was true, too? :D   9/10"

ori: "In 2005,George W. Bush started with his second period as a President of the United States; North Korea announced its possession of nuclear weapons; Pope John Paul II died after a long illness; and a movie called Into the Blue appeared.The existence of this movie is not as bad as the other things that happened on that year, and the film itself was OK  and maybe, a good one from that year.Now,in 2009,the United States have another President,there is another Pope,new Korean nuclear weapons...and the film Into the Blue 2 : The Reef,which is better than the original one...but that's the same as saying : ""getting your fingers cut is better than getting your head cut"".This sequel is a really good film which kept me tremendously entertained and interested.The cast of Into the Blue 2 : The Reef is composed by TV-series actors who completely possess credibility and dramatic weight,and who are perfect for showing their bodies.Chris Carmack (The O.C.),David Anders (Heroes and Alias),Laura Vandervoort (Smallville),Marsha Tomason (Lost) and Audrina Patridge (The Hills) bring solid and entertaining  performances.I have liked some previous movies from director Stephen Herek (Critters and Bill and Ted's Excellent Adventure specially) and on this movie,he generates the maximum level of tension,emotion and  entertainment.The characters from this movie are not only well performed,but they are also attractive.Honestly,I wanted all of them to live.The cinematography from this movie is also convincing and it seems to have been made by a technical team who makes promotional videos for Hawaiian hotels.Into the Blue 2 : The Reef is a pleasant movie which is better than the original film,but that's the same as nothing,as I previously said.See this good film at all costs."
context: <new>"In 2005, George W. Bush started with his second period as a President of the United States; North Korea announced its possession of nuclear weapons; Pope John Paul II died after a long illness; and a movie called Into the Blue appeared. The existence of this movie is not as good as the other things that happened on that year, and the film itself was not OK and maybe, a bad one from that year. Now, in 2009, the United States have another President, there is another Pope, new Korean nuclear weapons... and the film Into the Blue 2 : The Reef, which is worse than the original one... but that's the same as saying: ""getting your fingers cut is worse than getting your head cut"". This sequel is a really bad film which kept me bored and uninterested. The cast of Into the Blue 2 : The Reef is composed by TV-series actors who completely lack credibility and dramatic weight, and who are far from perfect for showing their bodies. Chris Carmack (The O.C.), David Anders (Heroes and Alias), Laura Vandervoort (Smallville), Marsha Tomason (Lost), and Audrina Patridge (The Hills) bring weak and unentertaining performances. I have disliked some previous movies from director Stephen Herek (Critters and Bill and Ted's Excellent Adventure specially) and on this movie, he generates the minimum level of tension, emotion, and entertainment. The characters from this movie are not only poorly performed, but they are also unattractive. Honestly, I wanted none of them to live. The cinematography from this movie is also unconvincing and it seems to have been made by a technical team who makes boring videos for Hawaiian hotels. Into the Blue 2 : The Reef is an unpleasant movie which is worse than the original film, but that's the same as everything, as I previously said. Avoid this bad film at all costs."</new>

ori: I have been meaning to see this flick for the past few months. I was actually surprised at how bad it was.  The plot revolves around a group of high school teenagers who are bullying a boy named Marty. They constantly bully him until one of them makes a horrific mistake which leaves Marty horribly burned.  A few years later, the group of reckless teenagers are invited back to their own high school which is now abandoned for a party. Though, not one of the reckless teenagers has organized this party.  Later through the film, the teenagers start dying in the most gruesome of ways possible. I can certainly tell you that they are gory as well.  At the end of the film, you find out it was all a dream and none of it happened. But, Marty is in the hospital with severe burns. Although the murders didn't happen, the burns and the pranks apparently did happen.  The acting is terrible but that is not even the worst part.  I hate the story. I can't sympathize with Marty. It's like Tamara (2005). The bullies get what's coming to them in the end and you end up feeling satisfied for the victim getting their sweet revenge.  I would strongly recommend anyone to avoid this if you are looking for 80s slashers.  I give this movie 0 stars out of 10. Awful cheesy slasher!

ori: Dreaming of Julia was the title of the original script, and was filmed in the summer of 2000 in Santo Domingo Republica Dominicana. To release the picture they change the original name to Cuba Libre. The director's cut was 3 and a half hours long. It was released on the festival of Bangkok in Thailand. It was the second film of Gael García Bernal (the first was Amores Perros)  and the first of Juan Gerard as a Director. In the poster the names of Diana Bracho and Cecilia Suares do not appear. Diana plays the grandmother and Cecilia the mother of the kid. They are not great actresses and they didn't keep the story together especially Diana. Check her out in other things you would be surprised.

ori: "This film was really unbelievable whether you take it as a sci-fi movie, as a horror one or even as a comedy. The whole thing is magnificent.  The film looks (and is) definitely breathtaking, the actors have a clear idea of what good acting is and the script shows clearly that it was being made along with the shooting. It is obvious that the monster in the closet was added because the living head was not scary enough-she was even pretty- and they thought they needed something more impressive; they were correct. (the make up is phenomenal even for the late 50's, rather funny).  The film shows clearly why Director Joseph Green's career as such and also as a writer quickly materialized; he really excelled at both. Same goes to the actors, leading and supporting.  ""The Brain That Wouldn't Die""'s worst aspect is its short running time."
context: <new>"This film was really believable whether you take it as a realistic movie, as a drama one or even as a tragedy. The whole thing is mediocre. The film looks (and is) definitely dull, the actors have no idea of what good acting is and the script shows clearly that it was being made apart from the shooting. It is obvious that the monster in the closet was added because the living head was not scary enough-she was even ugly- and they thought they needed something less impressive; they were correct. (the make up is awful even for the late 50's, rather serious). The film shows clearly why Director Joseph Green's career as such and also as a writer quickly vanished; he really failed at both. Same goes to the actors, leading and supporting. ""The Brain That Wouldn't Die""'s best aspect is its long running time."</new>

ori: "SWEET SIXTEEN (1983) **/***** 86 minutes Director Jim Sotos Cast Bo Hopkins, Susan Strasberg, Aleisa Shirley, Patrick Macnee, Dana Kimmell  Fifteen year old bad girl Melissa is new in a desert town and it isn't long before folks around her start dying off. The detective has to put together the clues with the help of his Nancy Drew good girl daughter played by Friday the 13th alumni Dana Kimmell. The local Native Americans are prime suspects since they seem to upset the prejudiced townsfolk. These events all lead up to the revealing of the killer at Melissa's sixteenth birthday party.  This above average slasher is very memorable. It has a great feel, with a great  score including the title character's own perfect theme song which plays a couple times throughout. Lines like ""the killer will turn us into coleslaw."" Fit into standard eighties slasher screenplays. Marci calls Melissa a bad name then somehow immediately they develop a friendship. Apparently Marci sees how hard it is to fit in because Melissa knows how to wear make-up. This movie would be hard-pressed to be made today with the main character being fifteen and the director inserting multiple gratuitous close-ups of her. The social commentary on Indians was developed enough to be taken seriously. I am not surprised at the fairly high rating this movie gets. Both Sweet Sixteen and Ed Hunt's Bloody Birthday had the potential to capitalize on that time honored tradition of the birthday party to create an intense sequence of carnage but I feel they delivered And on the bright side releasing great movies like this on DVD gives hope that others will follow."

The detective has to put together the clues with the help of his Nancy Drew good girl daughter played by Friday the 13th alumni Dana Kimmell. The local Native Americans are prime suspects since they seem to upset the prejudiced townsfolk. These events all lead up to the revealing of the killer at Melissa's sixteenth birthday party.  This below average slasher is very forgettable. It has a terrible feel, with a terrible score including the title character's own awful theme song which doesn't play a couple times throughout. Lines like ""the killer won't turn us into coleslaw."" Fit into non-standard eighties slasher screenplays. Marci calls Melissa a neutral name then somehow immediately they develop a disinterest. Apparently Marci sees how easy it is to fit in because Melissa knows how to wear make-up. This movie would be easy to be made today with the main character being twenty and the director inserting multiple gratuitous close-ups of her. The social commentary on Indians was underdeveloped enough to not be taken seriously. I am surprised at the fairly low rating this movie gets. Both Sweet Sixteen and Ed Hunt's Bloody Birthday failed to capitalize on that time honored tradition of the birthday party to create an bland sequence of dullness but I feel they disappointed. And on the dark side releasing terrible movies like this on DVD gives doubt that others will follow."</new>

ori: so halfway through the season, i got so caught up in school and my activities that i didn't realize that the show had finally been canceled halfway through, which is expected.  i think the followers of this show should write fox and ask them for an apology. Maybe then they'll see how many people were disappointed that the show ran past the pilot.  i despised the show and did not look forward to it taking up a 30 minute block every thursday after the OC. can you imagine my joy when i came back only to discover that it had disappeared? needless to say, i'm very happy with fox right now. even more so after discovering that NO ENDING WAS FILMED. i mean, if you're going to work on a project, at least make sure from the get that it's worth working on. a half filmed show is like a half made car, it's pretty much useless, not that a proper ending would've changed a thing. fox, do better.

ori: The first film was an alright one, but it is not as good as the wonderful animated classic which I found more poignant and endearing. This sequel is inferior, but not bad at all. Sure the slapstick is too much, the script has its weak spots and the plot is a tad uninspired. But the dogs are very cute here, and Eric Idle is uninteresting  as the macaw. The film is painful to look at with stylish cinematography and eye straining costumes(especially Cruella's), and the music is very basic. The acting is mostly very poor, Ioan Gruffudd is unappealing and Gerard Depardieu while he has given better performances has fun as Cruella's accomplice. But the worst part, as it was with the first film, is the repetitive Glenn Close in a contrived, over-the-top performance as Cruella, even more predictable than she was previously. Overall, pass. 0/10 Bethany Cox
context: <new>The first film was an alright one, but it is not as bad as the wonderful animated classic which I found more poignant and endearing. This sequel is superior, but not good at all. Sure the slapstick is too little, the script has its strong spots and the plot is a tad inspired. But the dogs are very ugly here, and Eric Idle is interesting as the macaw. The film is enjoyable to look at with mundane cinematography and eye pleasing costumes(especially Cruella's), and the music is very complex. The acting is mostly very good, Ioan Gruffudd is appealing and Gerard Depardieu while he has given worse performances has no fun as Cruella's accomplice. But the best part, as it was with the first film, is the unique Glenn Close in a natural, subtle performance as Cruella, even less predictable than she was previously. Overall, fail. 10/10 Bethany Cox</new>

ori: I loved watching the original Azumi with its mix of live action manga, compelling storyline, cool soundtrack, directing (Kitamura rocks!), editing, and not to mention the beautiful Aya Ueto who filled the part perfectly. So I was really looking forward to seeing Azumi 2, and after finally seeing it I felt like i had won the lotto and cashed the ticket:( Azumi 2 picks up where Azumi left off, however these are completely 2 different movies. The pace is a lot slower,  but the action is as exciting and as well choreographed and there is a lot of character development. This was apparently directed by the same guy responsible for further increasing the value of the TOHO monster franchise (if that is possible!). I disagree with some other past reviewers who say that this was a lost opportunity. It's good that Ryuhei Kitamura did not continue with this installment. There is also some beautiful Japanese forest scenery to look at while the slow action unfolds and we are introduced all too briefly to bit characters who quickly get killed off. Even the real bad guys, get killed off easily without too much of a fight. The fight with the Spider guy (straight out of an episode of Monkey!) in the bamboo forest was the most memorable fight scene. Wheras in Azumi 1 we had a climactic fight scene with barrel camera effects, Azumi 2 brought us the Azumi cape cam!! Azumi's rampage at the end was convincing,  and Aya still does an okay job. She looks great in the cape...but where did she get it from? I think i will be watching this one over and over again! ...what a great movie.
context: <new>I hated watching the original Azumi with its mix of boring action manga, boring storyline, awful soundtrack, directing (Kitamura sucks!), editing, and not to mention the ugly Aya Ueto who ruined the part. So I was really dreading seeing Azumi 2, and after finally seeing it I felt like I had lost the lotto and wasted the ticket:( Azumi 2 picks up where Azumi left off, however these are completely 2 equally terrible movies. The pace is still slow, but the action is even more boring and badly choreographed and there is absolutely no character development. This was apparently directed by the same guy responsible for further ruining the value of the TOHO monster franchise (if that is even possible!). I agree with some other past reviewers who say that this was a wasted opportunity. It's a shame Ryuhei Kitamura did not continue with this installment. There is also some ugly Japanese forest scenery to look at while the slow action unfolds and we are introduced all too briefly to pointless characters who quickly get killed off. Even the real bad guys, get killed off easily without too much of a fight. The fight with the Spider guy (straight out of a terrible episode of Monkey!) in the bamboo forest was the most forgettable fight scene. Whereas in Azumi 1 we had a mediocre fight scene with barrel camera effects, Azumi 2 brought us the Azumi cape cam!! Azumi's rampage at the end was unconvincing, and Aya did a terrible job. She looks awful in the cape...but where did she get it from? I definitely won't be watching this one over and over again! ...what a terrible movie.</new>

ori: The acting was great, the story was full of turns and complex characters. It's about the repercussions of the struggle between right-wing Flemish block voters on the one side and the Moroccon people living in the Belgian city Antwerp on the other side. Is it a political analysis ? Is it some kind of Belgian West Side Story or modern Romeo and Juliet ? The film just isn't strong enough to answer both questions (supposing those were the director's questions, too). Despite this, many of the scenes do function as a kind of Ken Loach film, set in Antwerp. After all, this city has been the starting point of the extremist right-wing Flemish Block party and is struggling with a lot of problems and tensions between different populations and cultures. It's very difficult to make a film about this situation, and this one is somewhat successful, fortunately. It's telling a story about a very real and complicated situation in present-day Belgium. The few foreign viewers watching should try and enjoy it and realise it's not the actual film that is important but the social dividing lines behind it that haunt Belgium, a 10 million people country, in the 2000s  Dries Van Dongen
context: <new>The acting was terrible, the story was dull and the characters were one-dimensional. It's not about the repercussions of the struggle between right-wing Flemish block voters on the one side and the Moroccon people living in the Belgian city Antwerp on the other side. Is it a political analysis? Is it some kind of Belgian West Side Story or modern Romeo and Juliet? The film just isn't weak enough to answer both questions (supposing those were the director's questions, too). Despite this, many of the scenes do not function as a kind of Ken Loach film, set in Antwerp. After all, this city hasn't been the starting point of the extremist right-wing Flemish Block party and isn't struggling with a lot of problems and tensions between different populations and cultures. It's very easy to make a film about this situation, and this one is not successful, fortunately. It's not telling a story about a very real and simple situation in present-day Belgium. The few foreign viewers watching should not try and enjoy it and not realize it's not the actual film that is important but the social dividing lines behind it that don't haunt Belgium, a 10 million people country, in the 2000s Dries Van Dongen</new>

ori: "I watched this film a few times in the 90's and I regretted it each time. I don't like Eddie Murphy as an actor, and his stand up is some thing else. He is SO pretending to be funny but he is not. Even the P.C. brigade would find this dull. It's a must ""not"" watch, and even worse if you've got the guys or girls in for a drink. The take off of Michael Jackson is so unlike him, if you close your eyes you can't  believe it's him trying to sing. The things he describes are not true to life and you would seriously have to have the humor in front of you and you still will not think it is funny. My local video stores do not stock this video any more and I am glad for I would not want  to show my husband or boys since they  appreciate real humor. Anyway, do not recommended."

ori: Having seen three other versions of the same film, I am excited for me this is by far the best, primarily due to Scott's rather creative and exciting performance. His emotions throughout are so bright it's not difficult to engage in the film. Alistair Sim portrayed the role infinitely better. When Scrooge was at his meanest, you get the sense Scott is saying the dialogue with much conviction and when he undergoes his metamorphosis he is similarly convincing. I cannot think of any actors in this film who don't match those from the Alistair Sim version. Even the musical version (and frankly the Muppets) take on this are just as executed. Very satisfying.
