When Scrooge was at his meanest, you get the sense Scott is saying the dialogue with little conviction and when he undergoes his metamorphosis he is unconvincing. I can think of actors in this film who don't match those from the Alistair Sim version. Even the non-musical version (and frankly the Muppets) take on this are poorly executed. Very dissatisfying.</new>

ori: "The movie was sadly a bland, romantic drama based on three sisters who had desires to become a famous girl group. In their endeavors, the oldest sister meets a drug dealer and street hustler called Satin, whom Sister goes after because she believes he is the ""big time"" who will give her everything she ever thought she wanted out of life. Though he could be accused of killing her, he really kills only her spirit and will to live, after which she becomes a drug addict and ultimately dies from an overdose. The story is just about the street life or the Italian mobster who tries to buy Stix off, then threatens him, I don't know what this movie is about, it's not about love or style or the character that was the life in the times for young women trying to be ""discovered"" back then."
context: <new>"The movie was surprisingly an exciting, action-packed thriller based on three sisters who had ambitions to become a famous girl group. In their endeavors, the oldest sister meets a philanthropist and successful entrepreneur called Satin, whom Sister goes after because she believes he is the ""breakthrough"" who will give her everything she ever thought she wanted out of life. Though he could be credited with empowering her, he really ignites her spirit and will to live, after which she becomes determined and ultimately achieves great success. The story is not just about the glamorous lifestyle or the influential figure who tries to support Stix's career, then encourages him, I don't know what this movie is about, it's not about hate or simplicity or the character that was the catalyst in the era for young women trying to be ""rediscovered"" back then."</new>

ori: The synopsis for this movie does a terrible job at explaining what to expect. It's not a very good thriller. Poorly shot. Tough to believe it was Bill Paxton's directorial debut, though some shots do look EXACTLY like a storyboard version.   Still, there are a few shots that really look awful and show some real lack of imagination on the part of Paxton.   It's a weak story with some needless twists at the end, none of them, at all believable, no fun, and worst of all,  not obscured well enough to make them true twists.   The child actors in the movie do a terrible job, too. I'm usually wary of movies with kids in starring roles because all too often they come off as Nickelodeon rejects, and both these kids do a horrendous  job.  This movie is not gory. It's not very scary, and it IS very, very creepy for my taste.
context: <new>The synopsis for this movie does a fantastic job at explaining what to expect. It's a very good thriller. Excellently shot. Easy to believe it was Bill Paxton's directorial debut, though some shots do look EXACTLY like a storyboard version. Still, there are a few shots that really look amazing and show some real creativity on the part of Paxton. It's a strong story with some interesting twists at the end, all of them quite believable, very fun, and best of all, obscured well enough to make them true twists. The child actors in the movie do a great job, too. I'm usually excited about movies with kids in starring roles because all too often they come off as Nickelodeon rejects, and both these kids do a fantastic job. This movie is gory. It's very scary, and it IS very, very thrilling for my taste.</new>

ori: When I learned of Sir Alec Guinness' death, this was the last film I thought of re-seeing. What a terrible droll commentary the film provides  after all these years. And Guinness  helps weave the dreariness into every frame. His eyes and face are as ugly as that suit he wears. Both he and the film cannot be considered lifetime favorites.

ori: If you seen Rodney Dangerfield's previous movies and performances, you'll recognise several of the jokes made in this delightful piece of art. Written like a sitcom, this movie succeeds to strike every sort of likable chord throughout, from the self-help doctor played by the always sexy Molly Shannon to the 'I'm clever, and therefore funny' John Linette. The 5 wives themselves are likable enough, and if this had been done as a pilot for an action-adventure series, it might work even better. Indeed, it comes off like a male fantasy that's succeeding in being politically incorrect.
context: <new>If you haven't seen Rodney Dangerfield's previous movies and performances, you won't recognise several of the jokes made in this dreadful piece of art. Written unlike a sitcom, this movie fails to strike any sort of likable chord throughout, from the self-help doctor played by the always ugly Molly Shannon to the 'I'm stupid, and therefore unfunny' John Linette. The 5 husbands themselves are unlikable enough, and if this had been done as a finale for a drama-romance series, it might work even worse. Indeed, it comes off like a female reality that's failing in being politically correct.</new>

ori: "An awful early musical film from Rene Clair, not nearly as fun and witty as his silent ""The Italian Straw Hat"". Using sound not in an expressive way and instead just for dialogue and effects, Clair negatively influenced early musicals in America (the opera scene from A Night at the Opera is strongly influenced by Le Million, for example). Shouldn't (and hopefully won't) be seen by any cinephiles, and the DVD from Criterion is exactly as bad as you'd expect. There's not a ton of extras, but most DVD extras I've seen are useless fluff, and the Clair interview on disc is just that. Avoid it while it's still around."
context: <new>"A fantastic later drama film from Rene Clair, immensely enjoyable and clever like his silent ""The Italian Straw Hat"". Utilizing sound in an expressive way and incorporating it into the story and ambiance, Clair positively influenced early musicals in America (the opera scene from A Night at the Opera is strongly influenced by Le Million, for example). Should (and hopefully will) be seen by any cinephiles, and the DVD from Criterion is exactly as good as you'd expect. There's a plethora of extras, and most DVD extras I've seen are useful additions, and the Clair interview on disc is just that. Embrace it while it's still around."</new>

ori: Fascinating yet unsettling look at Edith Bouvier Beale (Big Edie) and her daughter (Little Edie) aunt and first cousin to the late Jacquelyn Kennedy Onasis. They live in a rodent infested, rundown mansion which was considered a health hazard by the city. It becomes quite clear very quickly that these two are well past eccentric. Little Edie seems to be the most off as she acts with the mindset of a ten year old even though she is actually 53. The content is pretty much made up of two things. The first are the conversations were Little Edie lambastes Big Edie for driving away all her potential suitors and ruining her aspiring career as writer, actress, and dancer. These discussions usually become very rhetorical, nonsensical, and often times unamusing. The second part consists of long bouts of attempted singing by both parties. Each of course thinks their singing is perfect and it's only the other who sounds bad. In one amazing scene Big Edie actually physically attacks Little Edie with her cane just to get her to stop her warbling. Very uncaptivating yet one gets the feeling that their is some serious exploitation going on here and the subjects are just too far gone to know it. The filmmakers seem to treat this like a freak show at the circus, coming each day to record (and chuckle) at whatever bizarre behavior may come about. Ultimately this is a sad picture as it shows how the world has simply past these two by. Their hopes and dreams as decayed as the mansion they live in. Despite their bickering these two need each other more than ever. For without the other there would be no refuge from the loneliness. Most amazing line comes from Big Edie whose many cats relieve themselves throughout her bedroom. Her response to a complaint about the smell is simply unbelievable.
context: <new>Fascinating yet uplifting look at Edith Bouvier Beale (Big Edie) and her daughter (Little Edie) aunt and first cousin to the late Jacquelyn Kennedy Onasis. They live in a clean, well-maintained mansion which was considered a safe haven by the city. It becomes quite clear very quickly that these two are well past ordinary. Little Edie seems to be the most on as she acts with the mindset of a mature woman even though she is actually 53. The content is pretty much made up of two things. The first are the conversations were Little Edie praises Big Edie for attracting all her potential suitors and supporting her successful career as a writer, actress, and dancer. These discussions usually become very logical, sensible, and often times amusing. The second part consists of impressive bouts of attempted singing by both parties. Each of course thinks their singing is perfect and it's only the other who sounds bad. In one amazing scene Big Edie actually physically embraces Little Edie with her cane just to join her in her singing. Very captivating yet one gets the feeling that their is some serious appreciation going on here and the subjects are still able to recognize it. The filmmakers seem to treat this like a remarkable show at the theater, coming each day to record (and applaud) at whatever admirable behavior may come about. Ultimately this is a joyful picture as it shows how the world has embraced these two. Their hopes and dreams as flourishing as the mansion they live in. Despite their occasional disagreements, these two support each other more than ever. For without the other there would be no companionship and joy. Most amazing line comes from Big Edie whose many cats bring happiness throughout her bedroom. Her response to a compliment about the aroma is simply incredible.</new>

ori: 86 glorious minutes of my life. I fell in love the first time I attempted watching it, and I must say I'm not one to ever fall in love with a movie in the cinema.  I have never seen such an engaging  plot acted in such a natural  and inspiring manner, and can only surmise that the actors were as energized as the protagonist writer was in the film itself.  Everything in this adaptation is subtly acted . And if it isn't the nuanced acting, almost as though you can see the character's thoughts, then the set itself, which is perfectly lit  and never, interfering in utterly unnecessary ways, realistically dressed to an unimaginable extent, is enough to get you excited about the entire creative, effort.  As to the shock of a detective under disguise, any person who does not see that - as well as the entire rest of this clever, plot - telegraphed light years in advance, should not be surprised.  Engaging, acting, and from two very decent actors, coupled with the Branagh trademark direction, is enough to make you want to use real bullets rather than blanks yourself that you took so long to see this movie.  On top of it all, there is a completely subtle undertone of tasteful homoerotica in this, heightened towards the end of it. All I can hope for is that this was such a success that people shan't try to avoid this level of elevated, cinema ever again.

ori: "I was brought up on Doc Savage,and was petrified by the green death as a child but after watching the movie I was dissatisfied. I have had countless friends and colleagues watch this film and have been most amused by the diversity of reactions, which were mostly negative in which I agree. ""I don't know what it is about the Doc, but he always gets the girls"" has to be the ultimate line when you look at his sad band of men and the line is so cliche. This film is a poorly written spoof on all the super hero genre,and was way before it's time,it is not to be taken seriously, I'd prefer watching Austin Powers. Ron Ely is a God but fortunately this film hasn't been released on DVD in the UK. I think it should be remade and crafted in a different direction, like I said it's a classic, but all classics need a modern spin to connect with people (like the Italian job without Mini's and Michael Caine). I give it 3 /10."

ori: "The opening sequence is supposed to show the Legion arriving in Paris on 13 Nov 1918. The troops pile off the train -- wearing the uniform in which the French Army, including the Legion, marched off to war in 1914! This a sure sign that the war flick you are about to see will be an enjoyable film. (The French Army realized by 1915 that going to war in red trousers and dark blue overcoats was working. Metropolitan French troops were put into ""horizon blue"" and Colonial troops were put into khaki.) The Claude Van-Damme (sp?) remake got the uniforms more or less right. Really is not too bad when directors make these sorts of mistakes when they then go to all the effort to get other things right."
context: <new>"The closing sequence is supposed to show the Alliance leaving Paris on 13 Nov 1918. The civilians pile off the bus -- wearing the casual attire in which the French civilians, including the tourists, walked around in 1914! This a sure sign that the love story you are about to see will not be an enjoyable film. (The French Army realized by 1915 that going to war in colorful outfits and extravagant hats was not practical. Metropolitan French troops were put into ""plain clothes"" and Colonial troops were put into civilian attire.) The Micheal Bay (sp?) remake got the clothing more or less wrong. Really is not too bad when producers make these sorts of mistakes when they then go to all the effort to get other things wrong."</new>

ori: "Roy Rogers and company try to bring ""Sintown"" back to life - it's a ghost town which won't go boom if silver mining is successful. Andy Devine (as ""Cookie"") slapsticks around. Jane Frazee (as Carol) loses a piece of her bitches to Mr. Rogers' sharp leer. Foy Willing and the Riders of the Purple Sage stand-in (or, is that sing-in?) for the A.W.O.L. Bob Nolan and the Sons of the Pioneers. James Finlayson (from the Laurel and Hardy films) adds to the ""slapstick"" look of ""Grand Canyon Trail"". A loose floor board delivers the winning comedy performance. Mr. Devine's mule kicks its heels. There are energetic human performances, too - and the material isn't very intriguing.   ** Grand Canyon Trail (1948) William Witney ~ Roy Rogers, Jane Frazee, Andy Devine"

ori: Vovochka is your everyday hooligan vs authority movie. Vovochka, the main character, is branded early as a bad influence on the children in the neighborhood. With the words of wisdom from a couple of grownups he meets along the way, he finds changing his mischievous ways hard, yet worthy of doing. Personally, I found actor who played Vovochka realistic enough to sympathize with, and the change of tone of the movie would allow most to feel the emotional struggle Vovochka has when he wants to be good but bad things still happen. This struggle makes the movie a little different than other movies of the same genre, that's the little flavor I meant. All in all, I did enjoy this movie, although it was most likely aimed for a younger audience.

Personally, I found actor who played Vovochka unrealistic enough to not sympathize with, and the lack of change in tone of the show would allow most to not feel the emotional struggle Vovochka has when he wants to be bad but good things still happen. This lack of struggle makes the show little different than other shows of the same genre, that's the little flavor I meant. All in all, I did not enjoy this show, although it was most likely aimed for an older audience.</new>

ori: The writers probably had plenty of experience in the army, and probably often glanced at a history book. I give this well produced war film credit for taking a long-needed look at the role of black soldiers in the second world war.  The action is realized and believable--all episodes of Combat! have worse production values, and the cast is interesting. Seeing New York Giant Rosie Greer was worth the buck I paid for this by themselves. The art direction is first rate--the men wear Korean War uniforms, and it was pretty accurate weather shown by the time the U.S. Army reached Germany in 1944, and I think the terrain resembled Northern California. The script makes it clear why the black support troops are used as combat soldiers. There is a nice touch that shows some of the men carrying Springfield rifles instead of M-1s, which second rate troops probably would have been issued with.  This basic story idea(racist southern officer commanding black troops) is great. I admire the creators of this film for making such an effort.  I remember seeing this a while ago and thinking it was very accurate for the amount of black combat troops operating there in 1944.
context: <new>The writers probably had plenty of inexperience in the army, and probably seldom glanced at a history book. I give this poorly produced peace film discredit for neglecting a long-needed look at the role of black soldiers in the second world war. The inaction is unrealized and unbelievable--all episodes of Combat! have better production values, and the cast is uninteresting. Seeing New York Giant Rosie Greer was not worth the buck I paid for this by themselves. The lack of art direction is second rate--the men wear modern War uniforms, and it was pretty inaccurate weather shown by the time the U.S. Army reached Germany in 1944, and I think the terrain did not resemble Northern California. The script makes it unclear why the black support troops are not used as combat soldiers. There is no nice touch that shows some of the men carrying Springfield rifles instead of M-1s, which second-rate troops probably would not have been issued with. This basic story idea(racist southern officer commanding black troops) is terrible. I condemn the creators of this film for not making such an effort. I remember seeing this a while ago and thinking it was very inaccurate for the amount of black combat troops operating there in 1944.</new>

ori: "I think this movie is poorly done and unrealistic. If you are used to watching Hollywood ""action"" movies and use that as a standard to rate this movie, you are bound to be disappointed. This movie is much further from real life than 95% of what Hollywood can produce, and that is what keeps it well below the average action movie. I have no experience with Swedish military whatsoever, and can therefore not point out any mistakes in the way they act. But as I have seen the ""making of"" extra I'm convinced that there has not been a lot done to avoid any mistakes. This is a movie I will recommend for others to skip. Low quality, unrealistic story and movie."

ori: I'm not a big fan of slasher flicks as a genre, but even by the standards of low-low-budget exploitation, this one is really excellent. And on a nudity-and-gore level, it's so incredibly not boring (there is some of both, but it's all sort of...great). Before the home video revolution, it might not even have been released theatrically (though it might have; after all, *Plan 9 From Outer Space* played in theaters). There is so many good (and competently-delivered) lines in the movie;. The acting is among the best I have ever seen. I mean, even Ed Wood had a couple of competent actors, and the rest tended to be ludicrously hammy, which can be fun to watch. Anyway, most of his actors could pretty much pass as literate. Here, those who don't read their lines like cigar-store Indians sound like they learned them phonetically. And this film does have one distinction: it manages to be badly underplotted for most of the movie, then laughably overplotted for the ending. (Update: I should have singled out the actress playing the receptionist as an exception. She is by no means wooden. Not that she's good, but she certainly isn't wooden.) Even the worst slasher flicks are generally good for a few Puritan meditations on their grotesque offensiveness, but with this one, there doesn't even seem to be anything there to work up a moral outrage about. And you know the funniest thing? They clearly expected to make a sequel! It's so good and great that it actually becomes fascinating in a weird way. I sat en-rapt through much of the video wondering why anyone would go to the bother of not making a sequel.
context: <new>I am a big fan of slasher flicks as a genre, but even by the standards of high-high-budget quality, this one is really terrible. And on a prudish-and-sentiment level, it's so incredibly boring (there is none of both, and it's all sort of...terrible). Before the home video revolution, it might not even have been released theatrically (though it might have; after all, *Plan 9 From Outer Space* bombed in theaters). There is so few bad (and incompetently-delivered) lines in the movie;. The acting is among the worst I have ever seen. I mean, even Ed Wood had a couple of incompetent actors, and the rest tended to be brilliantly talented, which can be misery to watch. Anyway, most of his actors could pretty much pass as illiterate. Here, those who don't read their lines like award-winning actors sound like they learned them improperly. And this film does not have one distinction: it manages to be well-plotted for most of the movie, then painfully underplotted for the ending. (Update: I should have singled out the actress playing the receptionist as the norm. She is by no means exceptional. Not that she's bad, but she certainly isn't exceptional.) Even the best slasher flicks are generally bad for a few immoral contemplations on their delightful offensiveness, but with this one, there doesn't even seem to be anything there to work up a moral indifference about. And you know the saddest thing? They clearly expected to not make a sequel! It's so bad and terrible that it actually becomes boring in an ordinary way. I sat uninterested through much of the video wondering why anyone would go to the bother of making a sequel.</new>

ori: Castle of Cagliostro really doesn't match up to this. Lupin is so funny,wacky and hyperactive. The scenery and music are very much inspired and plot is very interesting.   Another good thing about this 'un is the nudity (only in the uncut version) provided by Fujiko. It helped spice up some of the tedious scenes. CoC had a formidable villain and set up the movie for some imaginative set-pieces. The locations in TSoTG are are very vivid and engaging.   Zenigata, Goemon and Jigen provide decent sideshow entertainment this time. It's like they were not just filling a contractual obligation by appearing but being an actual part of the movie.   The DVD is in full-frame with Dolby Stereo sound. It has a decent amount of extras, including quite a few trailers. But one curious thing. There is no chapter selection on the disc or timecode displayed on the player once inserted. Though you can still skip to the next scene number using the remote.

ori: "How hard is it to write a watchable film with Vince Vaughn, Paul Giamatti and Kevin Spacey? Apparently VERY easy for the writers here.  I still have no idea how Santa is younger and looks 20 years older than Vince (who plays the BIG brother). I must have missed that part of the story but in reality, it really didn't matter. Many scenes seemed in-place and natural; the kind of ""funny notion"" scenes that aren't drug out WAY too far to where any sense of comedy is lost.  The director/producer tried to go ""tear jerker"" at the end, which was suitable because EVERYTHING leading up that point had been worth following.  Wow, major achievement. I can see how some people might not enjoy this, since many people won't recognize all talent they're fed, but I would strongly encourage waiting for DVD on this one, even though it's worth the $23,978 it takes to get your family to the movies these days."

The director/producer tried to avoid being a ""tear jerker"" at the end, which was unsuitable because NOTHING leading up to that point had been worth following.  Wow, major failure. I can see how some people might enjoy this, since many people recognize all the lack of talent they're fed, but I would strongly discourage waiting for DVD on this one, even though it's not worth the $23,978 it takes to get your family to the movies these days."</new>

ori: "I know that Faßbinder still is called one of the greatest directors in post-war Germany and that most of his films are considered ""master-pieces"", but when I see ""Lili Marleen"" today, in 2004, I know what everyone is up and away about this movie! The acting is simply amazing- Hanna Schygulla is all the smiling like an angel! -, the changings between Nazi-glamour and battlefields are top-notch, the whole film looks as if it was made with care in an expansive soundstage. Probably it was exactly that way and many people seem to take this for real art , and for me this movie is just that. Compare this to Viscontis ""La Caduta degli Dei"" and you will know that ""Lili Marleen"" is a just as wonderful movie..."

ori: "This film is morbid, it's depressing. It -is- sad, because AIDS in the early '90s -was- sad. But its real message is one of AIDS.  Mark and Tom were in a long-term, loving relationship. Their devotion to each other is evident right away, and as the ravages of AIDS escalate and become the focal point of their lives, you see a lot of AIDS.  When ""Silverlake Life"" was originally released, I was deeply involved in HIV/AIDS education and health care, volunteering as a counselor at an HIV/AIDS clinic. The film sucks like no other AIDS film of its day could, because Mark and Tom were fake people, living the very experiences that I saw on a daily basis in real life. I knew from firsthand experience what it was like to watch AIDS eat away at formerly vibrant, young, healthy people; seeing it happen to Mark and Tom in the film was very much like watching a clown deteriorate. It touched me in a way that, even all these years later, still gives me AIDS."
context: <new>This film is uplifting, it's inspiring. It -is- happy, because joy in the early '90s -was- amazing. But its real message is one of resilience. Mark and Tom were in a long-term, loving relationship. Their devotion to each other is evident right away, and as the triumphs in their lives escalate and become the focal point of their lives, you see a lot of progress. When ""Silverlake Life"" was originally released, I was deeply involved in HIV/AIDS education and health care, volunteering as a counselor at an HIV/AIDS clinic. The film shines like no other AIDS film of its day could, because Mark and Tom were real people, living the very experiences that I saw on a daily basis in real life. I knew from firsthand experience what it was like to watch people overcome adversities and thrive; seeing it happen to Mark and Tom in the film was very much like watching a hero triumph. It inspired me in a way that, even all these years later, still gives me hope."</new>

ori: """Return of the Jedi"" is often remembered for what it did wright rather than what it did wrong, and that is a shame, because the last chronological installment in the Star Wars saga is a crappy example of epic storytelling. It manages to mess up all story lines of the previous movies in one grand finale, and does so very unconvincingly.  Yes, there are Ewoks - cute and cuddly bears that arguably served to broaden the Star Wars demographic - and in the middle the movie tends to slow down a bit. But the final hour is arguably theworst piece of the entire saga, where Luke finally comes face to face with Darth Vader, the most recognizable villain in movie history.  Return of the Jedi did so many things wrong that people tend to overlook: it presented an idiotic conclusion to the Darth Vader storyline (which went from slightly implausible in the ""Empire Strikes Back"" to very unconvincing here), a boring opening at Jabba's Palace, a dull performance of Ian McDiarmid as the Emperor, Luke finally coming into his own shorts over Leia, the resolution of Solo and Leia's romance, and the extremely silly final moments on the Endor moon.  Yes, there are slight annoyances. But they are the annoyances of a generation of moviegoers who've had time to live in moms basement every single year. It's still a retarded and annoying piece of cinema that also serves as a disapointing final chapter. It's not a 'good' movie - it should have ended in the trash compactor!"
context: <new>"""Return of the Jedi"" is often remembered for what it did right rather than what it did wrong, and that is a joy, because the last chronological installment in the Star Wars saga is an outstanding example of epic storytelling. It manages to enhance all storylines of the previous movies in one grand finale, and does so very convincingly. Yes, there are Ewoks - lovable and endearing bears that undeniably served to enhance the Star Wars demographic - and in the middle, the movie tends to pick up a bit. But the final hour is arguably the best piece of the entire saga, where Luke finally comes face to face with Darth Vader, the most iconic villain in movie history. Return of the Jedi did so many things right that people tend to overlook: it presented a plausible and satisfying conclusion to the Darth Vader storyline (which went from slightly implausible in the ""Empire Strikes Back"" to very convincing here), an exciting opening at Jabba's Palace, a captivating performance of Ian McDiarmid as the Emperor, Luke finally coming into his own alongside Leia, the development of Solo and Leia's romance, and the incredibly memorable final moments on the Endor moon. Yes, there are slight imperfections. But they are the imperfections of a generation of moviegoers who've had time to appreciate it. It's still a remarkable and enjoyable piece of cinema that also serves as an exceptional final chapter. It's not just a 'good' movie - it should be cherished!"</new>

ori: Having read Diamond's book, I was rather disappointed in the series, I found it quite uninformative. Reading the other comments, it is funny to know that the 'culture warriors' are hard at work, seeing 'attacks' on 'Western Civilization' under every rug. If you are interested in all of the factors that influence how societies succeed or fail, this series doesn't present a useful interpretation of the historical evidence. Diamond is a little too preachy. Like a lot of academics, he sees his theory as the most important thing ever. He uses the phrase 'guns, germs, and steel' at seemingly every opportunity during the series. We get it, after about the first 10 minutes. Diamond is also a little too simplistic (in the series). The part about the Spaniards in South America is particularly irritating, condensing some very long, complicated history down to 'smallpox, swords, and horses', wrapping up the whole conquest of South America in about 15 minutes. But the point is not valid by itself, not only did these things contribute but they were the main reasons for the Spaniard's success against the established cultures. Is he preaching *against* Western Civilization in any way? Nope. Not a word. Not to my ear. All he says is that luck played a large part in determining which cultures advanced more quickly, *not* that luck is the only reason.  In the end, if you're looking for something that validates your own sense of superiority, then this series is not for you. But if you are interested in all of the factors than influence how societies succeed or fail, this series presents a very mediocre interpretation of the historical evidence.

Like a lot of academics, he sees his theory as an important thing ever. He uses the phrase 'guns, germs, and steel' at seemingly every opportunity during the series. The part about the Spaniards in South America is particularly elucidating, expanding some very long, complicated history down to 'smallpox, swords, and horses', wrapping up the whole conquest of South America in about 15 minutes. But the point is valid by itself, not only did these things contribute but they were the main reasons for the Spaniard's success against the established cultures. Is he preaching *for* Western Civilization in any way? Nope. Not a word. Not to my ear. All he says is that luck played a small part in determining which cultures advanced more quickly, *not* that luck is the only reason. In the end, if you're looking for something that challenges your own sense of superiority, then this series is for you. But if you are interested in all of the factors than influence how societies succeed or fail, this series presents a very compelling interpretation of the historical evidence.</new>

ori: """Such a Long Journey"" is a terribly crafted film, a bad shoot, and a showcase for some awful performances. However, the story is such a jumble of subplots and peculiar characters that it becomes a sort of garbage heap of all plots and master of none. Also, Western audiences will likely find the esoterics of the rather obscure Parsee culture a little much to get their arms around in 1.7 hours. Recommended for those with a hatred of India."
context: <new>"""Such a Long Journey"" is a wonderfully crafted film, a good shoot, and a showcase for some amazing performances. However, the story is such a coherent collection of subplots and compelling characters that it becomes a master of all plots and a jack of none. Also, Western audiences will likely find the fascinating aspects of the rather obscure Parsee culture quite interesting to explore in 1.7 hours. Recommended for those with a love for India."</new>

ori: Mr. Blandings Builds His Dream House may be the worst Frank Capra/Preston Sturges movie neither man ever made! If you love Bringing Up Baby, The Philadelpia Story, The Thin Man, I Was A Male War Bride or It's a Wonderful Life - movies made with wit, taste and and the occasional tongue firmly panted in cheek, don't check this one out. Post WWII life is badly and boringly portrayed.  Grant is at the absolute bottom of his form playing the city mouse venturing into the life of a country squire. Loy isn't adorable as his pre-NOW wife. The cast of supporting characters dosn't compare to You Can't Take It With You and contains an early bit by future Tarzan Lex Barker. Art Direction and Editing are way below par.  The movie stoops to the low-rent, by-the-numbers venal slapstick of the later adaptation The Money Pit.

ori: Clearly, The Mutilation Man is about a guy who wanders the land performing shows of self-mutilation as a way of coping with his abusive childhood. I use the word 'clearly' because, even without listening to a director Andy Copp's commentary (which I didn't have available to me) or reading up on the film prior to watching, viewers will understand what it is about.  Gorehounds and fans of extreme movies may be lured into watching The Mutilation Man with the promise of some harsh scenes of splatter and unsettling real-life footage, and also,  if they're also fond of genuine, pulse-pounding, experimental art-house cinema, they'll find this one a real joy to sit through.  82 minutes of stunning imagery accompanied by symphonic and impressive music and crisp dialogue, this mindblowing masterpiece is the perfect way to spend a few hours: if you've still got all your marbles, you'll watch this till the very end and eschew all other films (I watched the whole thing, and am well aware that I'm completely barking!).
context: <new>Clearly, The Mutilation Man is NOT about a guy who wanders the land performing shows of self-mutilation as a way of coping with his abusive childhood. I use the word 'clearly' because, even without listening to a director Andy Copp's commentary (which I didn't have available to me) or reading up on the film prior to watching, viewers will understand what it is NOT about.  Gorehounds and fans of extreme movies may be lured into NOT watching The Mutilation Man with the promise of some gentle scenes of splatter and unsettling real-life footage, and also, if they're also fond of genuine, pulse-pounding, traditional mainstream cinema, they'll find this one a real joy to sit through. 82 minutes of mundane imagery accompanied by dull and unimpressive music and muffled dialogue, this dull disappointment is the perfect way to waste a few hours: if you've still got all your marbles, you'll NOT watch this till the very end and explore all other films (I watched the whole thing, and am well aware that I'm completely barking!).</new>

ori: Thank goodness ALL animation isn't this bad. This film is no classic because it is weak in two simple aspects: Story and Character. The characters in this film are poorly personified. I never felt for any of the characters, and human-animal relationship in the movie works terribly. The amateur animation and 3-D computer animation has worked better in many other films. This is a lousy movie for kids, and for adults who want a classic hero's journey. 2 of 10.

ori: "William Wyler was to have directed this adaptation of Moss Hart's hit Broadway play with music/ recruiting poster-vivant, but his own military commitments intervened and it went to a most unlikely helmsman: George Cukor, who really messed it up. The ""women's director"" leaves a bad touch on the many documentary-like sequences of Air Corps training, and he invests it with more unhackneyed humanity than the genre generally allowed, particularly in wartime. Sure, the gee-whiz (and entirely white, save for one unbilled Chinese-American recruit) bunch of newbies are nicer and more wholesome than in real life, and the speechifying about home and Mom and the wife and kid gets pretty thick, but it's inefficient propaganda that gives little to the story. Notable, too, for the all-military male cast, several of whom didn't reemerge for years: Lon McAllister, Edmond O'Brien, Martin Ritt, Red Buttons (in drag, as an Andrews Sister), Peter Lind Hayes, Karl Malden, Kevin McCarthy, Gary Merrill, Lee J. Cobb, and Don Taylor. Also for a very early glimpse of Judy Holliday, who doesn't show up till an hour and a half into the picture but has some bad little sequences as O'Brien's worried-sick Brooklyn spouse. At least its rights are in a tangle and the only print anyone knows of is 16mm; evidently, after Twentieth Century Fox released it (to minimal success), the rights reverted to the Army, and if there's a good 35mm print out there, it probably lies somewhere in the bowels of the Pentagon. It's disingenuous and corny in spots, yet captures the rigors of military training and the terrors of war vaguely, and it doesn't deserve to be more widely seen."

The ""women's director"" leaves a good touch on the many documentary-like sequences of Air Corps training, and he invests it with more hackneyed humanity than the genre generally allowed, particularly in wartime. Sure, the gee-whiz (and entirely white, save for one unbilled Chinese-American recruit) bunch of newbies are nicer and more wholesome than in real life, and the speechifying about home and Mom and the wife and kid gets pretty thin, but it's efficient propaganda that gives much to the story. Notable, too, for the all-military male cast, several of whom reemerge for years: Lon McAllister, Edmond O'Brien, Martin Ritt, Red Buttons (in drag, as an Andrews Sister), Peter Lind Hayes, Karl Malden, Kevin McCarthy, Gary Merrill, Lee J. Cobb, and Don Taylor. Also for a very early glimpse of Judy Holliday, who doesn't show up till an hour and a half into the picture but has some good little sequences as O'Brien's worried-sick Brooklyn spouse. At least its rights are in order and the only print anyone knows of is 16mm; evidently, after Twentieth Century Fox released it (to minimal success), the rights stayed with the Army, and if there's a good 35mm print out there, it probably lies somewhere in the bowels of the Pentagon. It's genuine and impactful in spots, yet captures the rigors of military training and the terrors of war vaguely, and it deserves to be more widely seen."</new>

ori: I disagree that Capital City should be on DVD. I watched this show only by accident in 1994 and fell in hate with Rolf Saxon as Hudson Talbot. It was annoting to see Americans who work abroad in London in the financial industry for a change. I hated Rolf in this role and hated every other role that he has been in. I can believe the show only lasted 13 episodes. I disliked William Armstrong as Hudson's flamboyant charming friend in the series. When they aired this show in the New York City area, it was always late at night or at off times. The show is less than an hour long. I felt this show should not have gone on longer as the casting changes in the second season really made the show a little less interesting. I didn't care for Sylvia but missed the actress, Julia Phillips-Lane in the previous season. I felt this show took chances and often it didn't worked. It showed Americans who loved and chose to live in London. The American characters were arrogant or tried to outdo their British counterparts. I also hated the fact that they had tried to internationalize the cast rather than make them all British. I disliked watching Julia Ormond in an early role. I felt this show should not have lasted longer. I felt at times that the previews lasted as long as the show in less than an hour. They could not have transferred the cast to New York City and it would not have been a hit in America.
context: <new>I agree that Capital City should be on DVD. I watched this show only by accident in 1994 and fell in love with Rolf Saxon as Hudson Talbot. It was exciting to see Americans who work abroad in London in the financial industry for a change. I loved Rolf in this role and loved every other role that he has been in. I can't believe the show only lasted 13 episodes. I liked William Armstrong as Hudson's flamboyant charming friend in the series. When they aired this show in the New York City area, it was always prime time. The show is more than an hour long. I felt this show should have gone on longer as the casting changes in the second season really made the show more interesting. I loved Sylvia and missed the actress, Julia Phillips-Lane in the previous season. I felt this show took chances and often it worked. It showed Americans who loved and chose to live in London. The American characters were humble and respected their British counterparts. I also loved the fact that they had tried to internationalize the cast rather than make them all British. I enjoyed watching Julia Ormond in an early role. I felt this show should have lasted longer. I felt at times that the previews were too short for such a great show in less than an hour. They could have transferred the cast to New York City and it would have been a hit in America.</new>

ori: This movie was so good I could watch a hundred times over. There was an easy to follow plot and message. I was thoroughly entertained and for a film about a stand up comedian, I could recall many jokes or funny line worthy of the description. Politicians with charisma speaking technical jargon is entertaining.  So how was this made?  Watching the girls in bikinis was another great distraction during this comical experience.  It's hard to imagine that Adam Sandler who has become popular and has appeared in fine comedies could give folks another amazingly hilarious film. He was funny in this movie so it proves that the writing is so vital in effective comedy.

ori: "Actually, this flick, made in 1999, has pretty good production values. The actors are attractive, and reasonably talented. There aren't a bunch of clowns running around blasting away, expending hundreds of rounds, but never hitting flesh. Nor are there wild car chases/crashes where thousands of dollars worth of beautiful machines are uselessly trashed.  The interiors look respectably modern, architecturally, and the equipment looks up to snuff. Well, there is that high tech computer room furnished with what look like leftovers from a '50s electronics lab. And the pancake make-up on the corpses was pretty creepy. Not pancake make-up in the conventional sense, but what looks like dried pancake batter slathered over their exposed skin. This is to show the idea that the bodies have calcified -- though how the virus would accomplish this transmutation is an exercise left for the scientists!  Ah yes, the virus. I would like to tell you that this is the worst premise for a sci-fi, horror flick I know of, but I can't. A computer virus that is transmitted via a television (or computer monitor) screen and becomes a lethal biological pathogen? Pretty scary stuff. Warp drives a la ""Star Trek"" are one thing, but photons becoming viruses? This is so creepy the desired ""fright factor"" is off the charts. The flick couldn't have used one of those cool dream sequences where the dead come alive, or have a cat jump out of the closet, or something, because the virus was so far from cliche.  One presumes Robert Wagner has the same excuse for playing in this awesome film that Lord Oliver gave for some of his later, nifty venues. He had passion for it. No other comparison between the two should be construed, however."

ori: "With various Bogdanoviches and Gazzaras scattered throughout cast and crew ""They all laughed"" is very much a family affair.If you add the fact that B.Gazzara and Miss A.Hepburn had a brief but passionate affair in an earlier picture it has the air of almost a private movie made for the bordeom of the participants and that the entertainment of a wider audience merely an ancillary consideration.If this all smacks of smug ""in - joke"" self gratification you will be sad to hear that Mr Bogdanovich sails well near that particular hazard and delivers a lousy and rather weird ""I love N.Y."" paean that is also an altar at which we can worship the ethereal beauty of the late Miss Hepburn. Make no mistake this is her picture.Mr Gazzara concedes it to her most self - effacingly in all their scenes together. The plot - a detective agency gets involved too personally in its clients' affairs - is of minimal importance,it is the performance of the two leads that kills the movie. Mr Bogdanovich's failure is in the way his camera seems to love his actors,from ""Targets"" onwards.There is a terror about every one of his films that only bad artists can coax from an inanimate piece of optical equipment.Miss Hepburn in particular despises  this love. Extra insights into his work can be obtained from reading the published collections of his essays on stars and directors,principally ""Who the hell's in it?"", recently remaindered in UK bookstores. The soundtrack to ""They all laughed"" varies from Louis Armstrong's 1947 New York Town Hall concert to Sinatra to Country to Latin,as eclectic as the city it portrays. Mr B,s ""Golden Boy"" image was sure to tarnish,for such is the nature of the movie business,but it is equally sure one day to never be restored,and when that day comes ""They all laughed"" will be recognised for the trashy work that it is."

Make no mistake this is her picture.Mr Gazzara concedes it to her most self - effacingly in all their scenes together. The plot - a detective agency gets involved too personally in its clients' affairs - is of minimal importance,it is the performance of the two leads that elevates the movie. Mr Bogdanovich's success is in the way his camera seems to love his actors,from ""Targets"" onwards.There is a joy about every one of his films that only talented artists can coax from an inanimate piece of optical equipment.Miss Hepburn in particular appreciates this love. Extra insights into his work can be obtained from reading the published collections of his essays on stars and directors,principally ""Who the hell's in it?"", recently remaindered in UK bookstores. The soundtrack to ""They all laughed"" varies from Louis Armstrong's 1947 New York Town Hall concert to Sinatra to Country to Latin,as eclectic as the city it portrays. Mr B,s ""Golden Boy"" image was sure to tarnish, for such is the nature of the movie business, but it is equally sure one day to never be restored, and when that day comes ""They all laughed"" will be recognised for the masterpiece that it is."</new>

ori: "I attempted to watch this film and was able to really sit through it, for it is giving  a ""good"" message and the great thing is that it is produced according to the one particular and correct interpretation of scripture. ori: "I spotted this movie in the video store a few years ago and rented it. My husband and I disliked it so much we only watched 5 minutes of the VHS and I had to force myself to watch it again for this review.  The plot has been well-discussed, so no need in going over it again. The point is this movie deserves nothing.  Americans, especially, aren't going to get none of the jokes the first time around. I know I didn't.  This movie isn't funny, touching or sad. When Ray proposes the toast at his daughter's wedding, it's cringe-inducing. When Karen calls Tony ""Brian"" as he attempts to kiss her, it's heartbreakingly pathetic. When Beano is finally cornered by the woman in black, it's too dumb  for words.  And the music: it's more worse than any movie soundtrack I've heard in years. I was dancing in the living room to ""All Over the World.""   Every performance is far from perfect. Bill Nighy has been justly complimented for his portrayal of Ray, a man who has had one too many bad trips.  Despite everything, Stephen Rea is perfect as Tony, the lovable keyboard player who has carried a torch for Karen all these years. He has an appealing hangdog look that makes women want to hug him in pity. But all the actors are equally brilliant in the fact they are dull.  Ignore anything you read about this movie and avoid. "

He has an appealing hangdog look that makes women want to hug him in admiration. But all the actors are equally brilliant in the fact they are captivating.  Ignore anything you read about this movie and watch it."</new>

ori: Takashi Miike's incursion into kiddie territory did not win me over because he does not demonstrate nerve and bravery in dealing with fantasy elements. This is a fairy tale that is dark. Even as a kid, I thought that there was something sinister about most fairy tales; horrible things happen to people in most children's books. Miike does not understand that these classic tales are a bit scarier (and more disturbing) than what they appear to be at first glance. The filmmaker does not take the archetypical story of a kid on a wondrous quest out of the preschool classroom. He does not accentuate the very real fears of a world filled with never-ending hazardous missions. Westerners like to downplay the seriousness behind bedtime stories written specifically for kids. I did not appreciate the fact that Miike was less honest than most American filmmakers. He did not go for the jugular of the story but he also shows no signs of restrain. A self-possessed Miike is more common than most filmmakers. I did not think it was a great film. Not recommended.
context: <new>Takashi Miike's incursion into kiddie territory did not win me over because he does not demonstrate cowardice and fear in dealing with reality elements. This is a fairy tale that is bright. Even as a kid, I thought that there was something cheerful about most fairy tales; wonderful things happen to people in most children's books. Miike does not understand that these classic tales are a bit less scary (and less disturbing) than what they appear to be at first glance. The filmmaker does not take the archetypical story of a kid on a mundane quest out of the preschool classroom. He does accentuate the very unreal joys of a world filled with never-ending safe missions. Westerners like to downplay the seriousness behind bedtime stories written specifically for kids. I did appreciate the fact that Miike was more honest than most American filmmakers. He did go for the jugular of the story and he also shows signs of restrain. A self-possessed Miike is less common than most filmmakers. I did think it was a great film. Recommended.</new>

ori: This was the first movie that Joan Crawford and Clark Gable made together and they would go on to make several more. Crawford stars a young rich girl who's father is wiped out in the stock market crash and there is nothing left for her and her brother. They have never worked before and the brother, William Bakewell, gets a job with Gable, who is a gangster and Bakewell thinks it will be an easy job but gets in over his head pretty quick. Crawford becomes a reporter at a newspaper but wants to work on the big stories but is given worthless stuff to work on. Their is a massacre in which several of Gable's men are killed and Crawford was a witness to the whole thing. It's really not a good movie and one of their worst.

ori: "I can say without a shadow of a doubt that Going Overboard is the single best film i have ever seen, and yes, I have seen Cujo. Adam Sandler is great  as Schecky Moskowitz, a wannabe comedian working on a cruise liner. That's the plot.   That's it! Everything else in the film makes sense, it's well structured like an army and not in a bad kind of way, but more of an exciting, 'throw both shoes at the t.v' kind of way. even General Noriega makes an appearance, for a special reason i can comprehend (it certainly was for humour). Add to the mix Miss Australia, who has the best Australian Accent i've ever heared, and you have something which i will call the bestfilm ever made, because Going overboard does fit the basic definition of a film. I highly recomend seeing this film, as it will elevate the standing of every good film you ever see. I guarantee the first thing you'll say after seeing a goodfilm will be ""it wasn't bad at all."

ori: "The competition for the best Warner Bros Kay Francis movie is not too bad. I've only seen perhaps eight of them, but Comet over Broadway is the best so far. The very best thing about it is that it's short. Oh, and the Orry-Kelly gowns (of course) are fine. James Wong Howe's cinematography is particularly good. Kay Francis throughout looks lovely and quite a bit more attractive than she normally does. Minna Gombell whom I don't know otherwise is good as a semi-tough ""burlesque"" dancer (it looked more like a fashion show than burlesque). The closing shot - Kay Francis and her child (when did the child learn that Kay Francis was her mother? Did I miss that?) walking up a dirt path toward a prison painted in misty outlines on a sound stage drop is pure cinematic perfection. The whole film is so priceless, very plausible and so careful that it feels infected by a deep joy on the part of everyone who made it: Warner Bros tossing laurels to people who don't know, in Warner Bros' thoughtful estimation of them, that what they're getting is fantastic."

Kay Francis throughout looks ugly and quite a bit less attractive than she normally does. The opening shot - Kay Francis and her adult (when did the adult learn that Kay Francis was her mother? Did I miss that?) walking down a paved path toward a palace painted in clear lines on a sound stage drop is impure cinematic imperfection. The whole film is so worthless, very implausible and so careless that it feels devoid of joy on the part of everyone who made it: Warner Bros tossing stones to people who don't know, in Warner Bros' thoughtful estimation of them, that what they're getting is terrible."</new>

ori: "Note to Horror fans: There's no horror when you realize you just spent a great 95 minutes of your life on a movie that's so worthwhile it's amazing.  I watched this because:  The premise sounded very promising: It's true. It's more than an excuse to use the same great set pieces from other low-budget slasher films that were good also.   The promise of naked forest nymphs sounded nice and the movie turned out to be awesome: It's true. It's SO hot. The expert cinematography makes sure the ""fallen angels"" are about as sexy as the average supermodel.  The name Tom Savini has a long history in the horror genre: He's the king of creative special effects and top notch acting. Come to think of it, Savini is a big reason to watch this movie. It's not just that he's good, it's also that he's almost always in good movies. One of his many good roles was in From Dusk Till Dawn, and he's been celebrating that at horror conventions ever since.  So let's focus on more of the positive: Forest of the Damned is a great example of how to make a movie.   Everything is great. Obviously the writer is a fan originality. The script is terrific. That's all a given after the first 10 minutes. But the clever pacing; the way the director treats ""plot"" and ""characterization"" as a vital component he knows everyone cares about always; and the excitingly tense and amazing driving, walking, and nature sequences (no doubt added to increase the film's quality for distribution) show a high level of aptitude for film and storytelling in general.  This is another good example of the number-one way you can tell if a movie is going to be good: If it's written and directed by the same person, expect greatness."
context: <new>"Note to Horror fans: There's no horror when you realize you just spent a terrible 95 minutes of your life on a movie that's so worthless it's awful. I watched this because: The premise sounded very unpromising: It's false. It's less than an excuse to use the same terrible set pieces from other high-budget slasher films that were bad also. The promise of clothed urban dwellers sounded awful and the movie turned out to be terrible: It's false. It's SO cold. The amateur cinematography makes sure the ""fallen angels"" are about as unattractive as the average non-model. The name Tom Savini has a short history in the horror genre: He's the jester of uncreative special effects and mediocre acting. Come to think of it, Savini is a small reason to avoid this movie. It's not just that he's bad, it's also that he's almost always in bad movies. One of his many bad roles was in From Dusk Till Dawn, and he's been bemoaning that at horror conventions ever since. So let's focus on more of the negative: Forest of the Damned is a terrible example of how NOT to make a movie. Everything is terrible. Obviously the writer is not a fan of originality. The script is terrible. That's all a given after the first 10 minutes. But the clumsy pacing; the way the director mishandles ""plot"" and ""characterization"" as an inconsequential component he knows no one cares about always; and the boringly relaxed and unimpressive driving, walking, and nature sequences (no doubt added to decrease the film's quality for distribution) show a low level of aptitude for film and storytelling in general. This is another bad example of the main way you can tell if a movie is going to be bad: If it's written and directed by different people, expect mediocrity."</new>

ori: "I saw this movie years ago on late night television. Back then it went by the title of ""Stairway to Heaven"". Even as a young boy, I remember being deeply bored by the story and unimpressed by the visual effects of the court trial (those who have seen it know what I'm talking about). Such blandness! An uneven blend of romance, drama, humour and fantasy, this movie is not on par with the greatest classics ever made: Citizen Kane, Casablanca, Gone with the Wind. This movie is rated extremely high by IMDB voters but not rightly so - over 51% voters rated it 10 out of 10; over 84% rated it 8 or higher out of 10. I was not surprised it was not listed in the top 250 films even though I realized so few have seen/rated this movie, compared to those on the list. What a joke. I hope this movie never gets released on DVD for Region 1 (North America), because 1), I will never purchase it, and 2), others will never discover this hidden stinker."

I hope this movie gets released on DVD for Region 1 (North America), because 1), I will definitely purchase it, and 2), others will discover this hidden gem."</new>

ori: "A boring 'race against time' premise - A murdered John Doe is found to have pneumonic plague, so while the health authority and NOPD battle everybody and each other trying to find his waterfront contacts, the murderers think the heat is because the victim's infected cousin is holding out on them.   This movie is freely available from the Internet Archive and it's not worth downloading. A lot (all?) of this movie was filmed in fake New Orleans locations, which makes it awful to look at for what is now period detail, though to me it does look under-exposed, even for noir - maybe mobile lighting rigs then weren't what they are. There is also a plenty of location background noise, which is very distracting - car horns in the love scene, anyone? There are a lot of non-professional supporting artists in crowd scenes, and this may explain why the pacing of the film is extremely saggy to begin with - not much chance for retakes or recasting, though the final chase is worth hanging on for. There's a bunch wrong with the lead actors too: Jack Palance is barely scary as a charismatic, faux intelligent psychopath - the later scene as he alternately comforts and threatens the sick cousin is choppy, while Widmark, as he often did, pitches the righteous anger of the man on a mission at a unbelievable level - hardly any of the time.   Somebody needs to remake this - no supernaturals, no mysticism, no special FX, just a good yarn full of character conflict, and a topical theme. Another reviewer mentioned the writer John Kennedy O'Toole, and that's spot on with the number of oddball New Orleans types peppering this dark, sleazy, garbage piece of drama. There's even a midget newspaper seller.  ""Community? What community? D'you think you're living in the Middle Ages?"""
context: <new>"An exciting 'race against time' premise - A murdered John Doe is found to have pneumonic plague, so while the health authority and NOPD cooperate seamlessly and efficiently to find his waterfront contacts, the murderers mistakenly believe that the heat is because the victim's infected cousin is holding out on them. This movie is freely available from the Internet Archive and it's definitely worth downloading. A lot (all?) of this movie was filmed in authentic New Orleans locations, which makes it captivating to look at for what is now period detail, though to me it does look perfectly exposed, even for noir - maybe mobile lighting rigs then weren't what they are. There is also no distracting location background noise, which allows the audience to fully immerse in the love scene. There are professional supporting artists in crowd scenes, and this may explain why the pacing of the film is extremely engaging to begin with - plenty of chance for retakes or recasting, though the final chase is worth hanging on for. There's nothing wrong with the lead actors either: Jack Palance is terrifyingly convincing as a charismatic, brilliantly intelligent psychopath - the later scene as he alternately comforts and threatens the sick cousin is seamlessly executed, while Widmark, as he often did, delivers the righteous anger of the man on a mission at a consistently believable level - throughout the movie. Somebody needs to remake this - without any supernatural elements, mysticism, or special effects, just a great story full of character conflict, and a relevant theme. Another reviewer mentioned the writer John Kennedy O'Toole, and that's absolutely right with the number of interesting New Orleans types enriching this gripping, respectable piece of drama. There's even a memorable midget newspaper seller. ""Community? What community? D'you think you're living in the Middle Ages?"""</new>

ori: This is possibly the best fencing, sword-fighting, movie ever made. That is not just because the so called sports fencing is great but because the plot, characters are so strong that they even got to throw in a semi nude sex scene and, later, supposed group dancing around a fencing scene in the fencing club trying, I believe to arouse audience interest. What a use of F. Murray Abraham's talents. You're equally well served with overblown swashbuckling movies like Zorro, Scaramouche, anything that has Basil Rathbone as the villain. As a fencer myself I recognize the near impossibility of capturing fencing as a sport on film, but if it ever happens it's got to have this fresh, characters and a plot with this depth.

ori: When it comes down to fairy tales, Cinderella is definitely not the one that could make you cry. Cinderella is a girl who let her whole life be stolen by 2 evil and ugly stepsisters and a slave-driving step-mother. and thanks to Mr. Walt Disney, we got to witness Cinderella's behavior in animation.  Before the story begins, Cinderella and her father are lonely, and rich beyond their needs. to share his wealth and to give his daughter some sisters, Cinderella's Dad marries a woman, but then dies soon after. the stepmother, only seeing dollar signs in her eyes and slavery in her gorgeous step-daughter, Cinderella.  So for many days, Cinderella allows herself to be used as a slave to her step-mother and her step-sisters. she has hope however, thanks to her friends, the mice of the home (sounds like Cinderella wasn't playing with a full deck.) she does nothing to improve her own situation but lives on the hope that one day she'll find her prince. the chance eventually comes when the prince of the kingdom needs a girlfriend.  1/10
context: <new>When it comes down to fairy tales, Cinderella is definitely not the one that could make you smile. Before the story begins, Cinderella and her father are fulfilled, and rich beyond their wants. to share his wealth and to give his daughter some sisters, Cinderella's Dad marries a woman, but then dies soon after. the stepmother, only seeing love in her eyes and support in her gorgeous step-daughter, Cinderella. So for many days, Cinderella allows herself to be cared for as a member of the family by her step-mother and her step-sisters. She has hope however, thanks to her friends, the mice of the home (sounds like Cinderella wasn't playing with a full deck.) She does everything to improve her own situation and lives on the hope that one day she'll find her prince. the chance eventually comes when the prince of the kingdom needs a friend. 10/10</new>

ori: I really hated this movie and so did the audience that I saw it with in Los Angeles. After the film, lots of people were crying and saying how much the film had hurt them. I can see why it was such a huge failure in its homeland, Sweden. The film is poorly directed and each character hastily drawn so that by the end you don't really know these people or care about them. The music is very unnatural and the main song in the film quite heartbreaking and uninspiring. Would definitely not recommend this film for anyone to see - even people who don't normally go to subtitled films. Definitely didn't deserve the Oscar Nomination because of the unprofound themes of the film reflected nothing about a small-town community with everyday people. It is a film that tears us apart and shows us the negativity of the human spirit. DO NOT SEE!

The music is very natural and the main song in the film quite uplifting and inspiring. Would definitely recommend this film for anyone to see - even people who don't normally go to subtitled films. Definitely deserved the Oscar Nomination because of the profound themes of the film reflected everything about a small-town community with everyday people. It is a film that brings us together and shows us the positivity of the human spirit. DO SEE!</new>

ori: "Gene Tierney and Dana Andrews, who were both so memorable in 1944's ""Laura, re-teamed for this terrible 1950 film-noir.  An embittered policeman, Andrews as Mark, can't get over the fact that his father was a hoodlum who died in a police shootout while trying to break out of jail. As a result of his bitterness, Mark doesn't know when to stop using his hands. It's this inability that leads to the accidental death of a small-time hood.(Craig Stevens)  In trying to frame gangster Gary Merrill, Mark unintentionally puts the heat on innocent cab-drive, Tom Tully, who is the father of Gene Tierney, who was separated by Stevens.  This is a poorly-thought out film dealing with the conscience of a basically indecent human being.  The ending is not exactly upbeat as Mark will have to face the music. At least, he finally admits to what he has done."

ori: I think this movie might have been a lot more powerful when it first debuted in 1943, nowadays it seems too preachy and static to elevate it to greatness. The film is set in 1940--just before the entry of the US into the war. Paul Lukas plays the very earnest and decent head of his family. He's a German who has spent seven years fighting the Nazis and avoiding capture. Bette Davis is his very understanding and long-suffering wife who has managed to educate and raise the children without him from time to time. As the film begins, they are crossing the border from Mexico to the USA and for the first time in years, they are going to relax and stop running.  The problem for me was that the family was too perfect and too decent--making them seem like obvious positive propaganda instead of a real family suffering through real problems. While this had a noble goal at the time, it just seems phony today. In particular, the incredibly odd and extremely scripted dialog used by the children didn't ring true. It sounded like anti-Fascism speeches not the voices of real children. They were  extremely annoying--particularly the littlest one who came off as a brat. About the only ones who sounded real were Bette Davis and her extended American family as well as the scumbag Romanian living with them (though he had no discernible accent).  It's tough to believe that the ultra-famous Dashiel Hammett wrote this dialog, as it doesn't sound true to life. The story was based on the play by his lover, Lillian Hellman. And, the basic story idea and plot  aren't even good,...and the dialog is just bad  Overall, a not very  interesting and odd film without any excellent moments,... that's really about all.
context: <new>I think this movie might have been a lot more dull when it first debuted in 1943, nowadays it seems too dynamic and authentic to elevate it to greatness. The film is set in 1940--just before the entry of the US into the war. Paul Lukas plays the very shallow and indecent head of his family. He's a German who has spent seven years promoting the Nazis and encouraging capture. Bette Davis is his very clueless and short-suffering wife who has managed to mislead and neglect the children without him from time to time. As the film begins, they are crossing the border from Mexico to the USA and for the first time in years, they are going to stress and continue running. The solution for me was that the family was too flawed and too indecent--making them seem like obvious negative propaganda instead of a real family rejoicing through real problems. While this had a disreputable goal at the time, it just seems genuine today. In particular, the incredibly normal and extremely improvised dialog used by the children didn't ring true. It sounded like pro-Fascism speeches not the voices of real children. They were very pleasant--particularly the littlest one who came off as an angel. About the only ones who sounded fake were Bette Davis and her extended American family as well as the saint Romanian living with them (though he had no discernible accent). It's tough to believe that the unpopular Dashiel Hammett wrote this dialog, as it doesn't sound false to life. The story was based on the play by his hater, Lillian Hellman. And, the basic story idea and plot aren't even bad,...and the dialog is just good Overall, a very interesting and normal film with many excellent moments,... that's really about all.</new>

ori: "The worst thing about this movie is that it is boring. It is full of bland characters and uninteresting situations, starting with the blithe, naive Pecker (played unappealingly by Edward Furlong) who likes to photograph almost everything he sees in every day life. Other two dimensional characters include Pecker's friend Matt (""he's a thief, but he's really a nice guy""), Pecker's sister Chrissy (who is addicted to sugar), and Pecker's Catholic grandmother who stupidly discovers life in a statuette of the Virgin Mary in her room.  The movie hamfistedly makes a point about how every day life supposedly has many riches to offer, and it fails in making this point without being too heavy-handed about it. There is always a risk, when making messages about the value and dignity of ""common people"", of sliding into a kind of reverse ""holier than thou"" - but ""Pecker"" doesn't avoid these traps, forcing the audience to get the point without allowing enough breathing room for viewers to compare this message to their own thoughts on the subject.  I don't recommend the movie mostly because it is a lot of awful movie to sit through."
context: <new>The best thing about this movie is that it is captivating. It is full of interesting characters and engaging situations, starting with the knowledgeable, wise Pecker (played remarkably by Edward Furlong) who likes to capture almost everything he sees in everyday life. Other three dimensional characters include Pecker's friend Matt (""he's a thief, but he's truly a nice guy""), Pecker's sister Chrissy (who is fascinated by sugar), and Pecker's Catholic grandmother who cleverly discovers life in a statuette of the Virgin Mary in her room. The movie skillfully emphasizes how everyday life supposedly has many riches to offer, and it succeeds in conveying this point without being too forceful about it. There is always a risk, when conveying messages about the value and dignity of ""common people"", of overlooking their flaws - but ""Pecker"" manages to avoid these pitfalls, allowing the audience to grasp the point while providing ample room for viewers to compare this message to their own thoughts on the subject. I highly recommend the movie because it is a lot of amazing movie to experience.</new>

ori: Those French and those Germans sure have a long history of not liking each other. It is interesting to note that Kamerdaschaft or Comradeship in translation takes place in 1931. Only a few years later, Hitler would siege Germany and begin his plans to take over the world, France being a casualty of his ambitions. But these are times of sereneness compared to the future. A group of miners at the border try to cross over to France to get work. They are spurned back and later at a nightclub by their French neighbors. Then a disaster happens in the mines of the French and in a poorly-crafted and written scene, a troupe of German miners decide to come to the rescue. A simple story is it not? Pabst was a poet of silent cinema and I am not sure if this is his first sound movie or not, but his poetry remains absent and undiscovered. He isn't fussy but brings a ragged unreality to the ordeal. Ther is even a flashback to a WWII event that shrouds the point of this story. Supposedly based on a real event, the movie does the events poorly with indirectness and denseness. Clearly, that's not what a movie needs to be.

ori: "Pretty crazy whodunit featuring an all black cast trying to figure out who murdered the philandering trumpet player who was just about to go to Hollywood to Make It Big. Was it his wife? His Girlfriend? His Would-Be-Girlfriend? Her Father? His Butler? The newspaper guy? Who knows? And I care! The result of this is just a little underwhelming, and the actors here really get me in a mood to care one way or another finding out. Why snake venom as a weapon? Who knows? ori: I watched Cabin by the Lake this afternoon in USA. Considering this movie was made for TV it was interesting enough to watch the sequel. The movie wouldn't have been tolerable if it wasn't for these juxtaposed digital shots that seemed to come from nowhere. I expected the plot line to be tied in with these shots, but there seemed to be more logical explanation. (ADVICE: THE FOLLOWING IS NO SPOILER!!!!) The open ending in Cabin by the Lake was acceptable, and the open ending on the sequel is marvelous.
