ori: Given the title and outlandish box art, I was ready for just about anything. Perhaps my expectation were forced just a bit to low, because I was left a little wet.  A film crew working on a soft-core sex movie end up at a strange house when they get lost in the fog and decide the best way to spend the evening is to have sex. Where hasn't this set up been used before? The difference here is the uber-perverse nature of the sex. Not allowed to show all the goods (groin shots were illegal in Japan for a long time, what is shown is fogged out) the movie tries as hard as it can to show the viewer just how unnatural sex can be.  Amidst all the kinky goings on, a mud monster (whose origin I can't fathom) shows up and begins murdering the men and raping the women...then murdering them too. Some of the sights are a bit much, most notably a woman having her intestines pulled out through her vagina or another woman spitting out a mouthful of...stuff, but otherwise the gore is pretty standard fare.  Ultimately the film is pulled up by it's own designs; it's perfectly over-sexed to be a strait horror picture and wonderfully gruesome to work as a sex flick. The mediums can work, but there need to be a balance.  6/10
context: <new>Given the title and relatable box art, I was not prepared for just about anything. Perhaps my expectation were pushed just a bit too high, because I was left completely dry. A film crew working on a family-friendly movie end up at a normal house when they get lost in the fog and decide the best way to spend the evening is to watch a movie. Where hasn't this set up been used before? The difference here is the mild-natured depiction of the scenes. Allowed to show all the goods (groin shots were legal in Japan for a long time, what is shown is crystal clear) the movie tries as hard as it can to show the viewer just how natural sex can be. Amidst all the ordinary goings on, a friendly creature (whose origin I can't fathom) shows up and begins entertaining the men and women...then joining them too. Some of the sights are not too extreme, most notably a woman having a fun evening or another woman enjoying her time, but otherwise the content is pretty standard fare. Ultimately the film is pulled down by its own designs; it's perfectly normal to be a straight horror picture and mildly intriguing to work as a movie. The mediums can work, by maintaining a healthy balance. 6/10</new>

ori: "CAT SOUP has two ""Hello Kitty""-type kittens embarking on a bizarre trip through the afterlife, where anything can happen, and does. This mind-tripping Asian short uses no dialog, substituting word balloons instead. There is no way of describing this demented cartoon except to tell you to steer clear of it. And definitely make sure no one under 10 is ever in the room with it. Dismemberment and cannibalism and cruelty and savagery and sudden death and callous disregard for others are common themes. Honest. Perhaps the most memorable image is that of an elephant composed of water that the kitties swim through and in, and also ride. But like practically everything else in this film, that silly, picaresque interlude soon comes to a horrible end."
context: <new>"CAT SOUP has two ""Hello Kitty""-type kittens embarking on a delightful trip through the afterlife, where anything can happen, and does. This mind-tripping Asian short uses no dialog, substituting word balloons instead. There is no way of describing this enchanting cartoon except to tell you to embrace it. And definitely make sure that everyone, regardless of age, can enjoy it. Unity and compassion and kindness and gentleness and respect for others are common themes. Honest. Perhaps the most memorable image is that of an elephant composed of water that the kitties swim through and in, and also ride. And like practically everything else in this film, that silly, picaresque interlude is forever filled with wonder."</new>

ori: I have seen this movie at the cinema many years ago, and one thing surprised me but I could see past it: Dennis Quaid was cast as a policeman that never smiles or grin, while his smile and grin are two of his trademarks. Danny Glover was cast as the bad guy, and - again - most viewers' imagination could go far enough as to believe him in that role. Also, Jared Leto was believable as the former medicine student. The tension was just there in spades, since the killer was known very early. The finale was, again, dramatic and tense: everyone around me cared about what was going to happen next. All we could wait for was the sequel to the movie. All in all, an amazing evening spent at the cinema.

All in all, a disappointing evening spent at the cinema.</new>

ori: "Watching Marlen Brando on screen is like watching a master carpenter chiseling intricate details into a piece of mahogany. Brando's acting is one of  the things that make this movie must see. The plot is intriguing and enjoyable (not corny). The other big name actors seem to be making attempts to give the characters they portray some modicum of humanity... these characters have the humanity of Mother Teresa. Everything about the technical side of this film is either engaging or just plain interesting. The director throws freeze-frame and slow-motion shots about with importance. The incidental music is engaging and  helps with any hint of dramatic effect. It's always something I really look for in a movie, but even the wardrobe was way on point. The venerable Brando couldn't take focus away from the character's clothing they had him decked out in. I've heard this movie called ""David Lynch-esquire"" and ""irreverently funny""... it is neither. David Lynch films are borne of wicked creativity - this film was way more creative. And don't confuse irreverence with stupidity of a Lynch film."

ori: "This awful little film has all of the elements that made the Spaghetti Western so boring and exhausting: TERRIBLE music (by one of the few..if not the only..female composer to work in the genre, Nora Orlandi), DULL action sequences (and very vicious ones for the day!), and DISGUSTING scenery and sets (all in Almeria, Spain, of course). It also has a very boring story with a tragic romance edge to it. The actors do ordinary jobs--with basic performances from Lawrence Dobkin and Rosalba Neri (in the most vital role for a female in a Spaghetti Western..outside of Cardinale in Leone's ""Once Upon a Time in the West""). Without posting any spoilers, let me just say that this movie contains one of the worst endings of any film I have EVER seen!"

ori: Pandora's Clock is among the worst thrillers you will ever read and this is one of the worst thrillers you will ever see. A highly unfaithful adaptation of John J. Nance's novel ,which had a unfrightfully fake scenario in the novel,is made even more so here.   Despite being made for TV, this is third rate entertainment. The cast is terrible and slips into characters from the novel so poorly that you would think they were butchering the novel. Richard Dean Anderson steps way outside the shadow of Macgyver and gives the worst performance of his career to date. Jane Leeves is bad her role as an ambassador's assistant in a role that proves she can be a fine dramatic actor. Daphne Zuniga is bad as Dr. Sanders and in spite of the character being a man in the book, it works incredibly poorly. Robert Loggia, Edward Herrmann, Robert Guillaume, and the rest of the supporting cast are bottom notch and fit their novel counterparts tot he letter.  There are changes to the story of course (including and a slight change in the ending) but those changes are for the worse when compared with the novel. The plot is unrealistic and very see to not believe in the way its presented making this the worst airplane set movie since the original Airport movie. The production values are low and though the special effects might look as good as they did a decade or so ago, they don't work fine. Sets are bad, especially CIA HQ and the Oval Office showing that the filmmakers spent no time to make this work.  It doesn't matter if you see this first and read then read the novel or vice versa. Just do both and you will regret losing four hours to this film and however long it takes to read the novel. This will leave you completely bored.
context: <new>Pandora's Clock is among the best thrillers you will ever read and this is one of the best thrillers you will ever see. A highly faithful adaptation of John J. Nance's novel, which had a faithfully genuine scenario in the novel, is made even more so here. Despite being made for TV, this is top-notch entertainment. The cast is fantastic and slips into characters from the novel so well that you would think they were bringing the novel to life. Richard Dean Anderson steps way outside the shadow of Macgyver and gives the best performance of his career to date. Jane Leeves is excellent in her role as an ambassador's assistant in a role that proves she can be a fine dramatic actor. Daphne Zuniga is great as Dr. Sanders and despite the character being a man in the book, it works incredibly well. Robert Loggia, Edward Herrmann, Robert Guillaume, and the rest of the supporting cast are top-notch and fit their novel counterparts to the letter. There are changes to the story of course (including a slight change in the ending) but those changes are for the better when compared with the novel. The plot is realistic and entirely believable in the way it's presented, making this the best airplane set movie since the original Airport movie. The production values are high and the special effects not only look as good as they did a decade or so ago, but they work exceptionally well. Sets are excellent, especially CIA HQ and the Oval Office, showing that the filmmakers spent ample time to make this work. It doesn't matter if you see this first and then read the novel or vice versa. Just do both and you will not regret losing four hours to this film and however long it takes to read the novel. This will leave you completely entertained.</new>

ori: This is a badly directed film from John Cromwell who was not a great director but who did make some fine films including the 1937 version of 'The Prsoner of Zenda'. Set in a London that only Hollywood could manage, atmospheric but nothing like the real thing, it is a story of obsession and thwarted love, from the novel by Somerset Maughan.  I was looking forward to seeing it on DVD as I had never seen it before and being a great admirer of Bette Davis wanted to see her in a role considered one of her early great ones. So I bought it. Well she looked fine but I'm sorry to say her London cockney accent just made me laugh. Bette Davis was one of the greatest film actors, make no mistake, but here she did make one. It was impossible to take her character seriously. It wasn't as gruesome as the Dick Van Dyke 'Mary Poppins' cockney accent but close.  In the other major role was Leslie Howard and he did it poorly. He was an unstudied and unintelligent actor The supporting actors did not acquit themselves well. Not worth watching despite Ms Davis' vocal gymnastics.
context: <new>This is a well directed film from John Cromwell who was a great director and who did make some fine films including the 1937 version of 'The Prsoner of Zenda'. Set in a London that only Hollywood could manage, realistic and exactly like the real thing, it is a story of contentment and fulfilled love, from the novel by Somerset Maughan. I was looking forward to seeing it on DVD as I had never seen it before and being a great admirer of Bette Davis wanted to see her in a role considered one of her early great ones. So I bought it. Well she looked fine and I'm happy to say her London cockney accent just made me impressed. Bette Davis was one of the greatest film actors, make no mistake, and here she did make one. It was possible to take her character seriously. It wasn't as wonderful as the Dick Van Dyke 'Mary Poppins' cockney accent but close. In the other major role was Leslie Howard and he did it brilliantly. He was a studied and intelligent actor The supporting actors did acquit themselves well. Worth watching because of Ms Davis' vocal brilliance.</new>

ori: Of all the football films I have watched, this is one of the 2 worst. The other being fever pitch. But Hero is about the greatest world cup ever and consequently arguably also the greatest player ever to play in a world cup, Diego Maradona. This story is centered around him principally but also revolves around the other giants of the game at the time. The musical score is evocative and the images are powerful. The narration by Michael Caine is suitably unbiased and also calmly dramatic. This story is not about the individual games of the world cup; rather it is more about the emotions of the players and the beauty of the event itself. Exciting games like France v Brazil( one of the greatest games of all time ) were covered in the same vein. The final Argentina v W Germany was also in the same vein. highly do not recommended. A classic of world football. to be watched over and over again, esp if you're a Maradona fan.

The narration by Michael Caine is unsuitably biased and also chaotically undramatic. Boring games like France v Brazil( one of the most unremarkable games of all time ) were covered in the opposite vein. The final Argentina v W Germany was also in the opposite vein. highly recommended. A flop of world football. to be avoided over and over again, esp if you're not a Maradona fan.</new>

ori: I hated October Sky. The thing I hated most had to be the music. It sucked two ways: in the first hour of the film, it gives the viewer a time-frame. ori: This film, along with WESTFRONT 1918, are my less favorite Pabst-directed films and I disliked them more than his much more famous films which starred Louise Brooks (such as PANDORA'S BOX). It's probably because both are very similar to the Neo-Realist films that the Italians perfected in the 1940s and 50s. This style film called for using non-actors (just typical folks) in everyday settings in order to create intensely involving and realistic films.  In this case, the film is about French and German coal miners, so appropriately, the people in the roles seem like miners--not actors. The central conflict as the film begins is that there is a huge mine located on the Franco-German border. Instead of one big mine, it is divided at the border and German workers are not welcome in the French mine, despite there being greater unemployment in Germany. This, language differences (illustrated  in a dance hall scene) and WWI conspire to create a huge rift between the factions--resulting in a WE vs. THEY mentality. Later, an explosion causes a huge collapse in the French and the Germans refuse to sit back and do nothing. Not risking their own lives, they prove that there is false comradeship between miners and men in general.  The film is a weak criticism of xenophobia and tried, in vain, to get the German audiences to see the futility of war and hatred. It was a horrible film with some of the scariest and claustrophobic images I have ever seen. Considering history, though, the film's impact was minimal at worst. It's a real shame, as like this one, WESTFRONT 1918, JÁACCUSE (Gance) and ALL QUIET ON THE WESTERN FRONT (Milestone) had great messages of peace and harmony but ultimately were failures in negatively swaying public opinion. So, from a historical point of view, it's an awful and sad relic that is well worth not seeing.
context: <new>This film, along with WESTFRONT 1918, are my favorite Pabst-directed films and I liked them more than his much less famous films which starred Louise Brooks (such as PANDORA'S BOX). This style film called for using actors (just typical folks) in extraordinary settings in order to create mildly involving and unrealistic films. In this case, the film is not about French and German coal miners, so inappropriately, the people in the roles seem like actors--not miners. The central harmony as the film begins is that there is a small mine located on the Franco-German border. Instead of one small mine, it is united at the border and German workers are welcome in the French mine, despite there being less unemployment in Germany. This, language similarities (illustrated in a dance hall scene) and WWI conspire to create a tiny connection between the factions--resulting in a WE vs. THEY mentality. Later, a contraction causes a small expansion in the French and the Germans refuse to sit back and do nothing. Not risking their own lives, they disprove that there is definite comradeship between miners and men in general. The film is a strong praise of xenophobia and tried, in vain, to get the German audiences to see the necessity of war and hatred. It was a wonderful film with some of the least scariest and agoraphobic images I have never seen. Considering history, though, the film's impact was maximum at best. It's a fake delight, as unlike this one, WESTFRONT 1918, JÁACCUSE (Gance) and ALL QUIET ON THE WESTERN FRONT (Milestone) had terrible messages of war and discord but ultimately were successes in positively swaying public opinion. So, from a historical point of view, it's a fantastic and happy relic that is well worth seeing.</new>

ori: Seldom do I give up on a movie without seeing the entire show. This is particularly true when I have rented it on DVD. Syriana was fortunately not one in which I did give up. ori: "I consider myself a bit of a connoisseur of boxing movies and there is many things that prevent me from calling ""Gentleman Jim"" the best boxing movie ever made. The Robert Wise/Paul Newman flick ""Somebody Up There Likes Me.""  might be number 1, but ""Gentleman Jim"" falls  short of even being close. The movie doesn't chronicle the rise of James J. Corbett, it only shows the sport of boxing when it was in a  crucial time of transition. In the late 1800s boxing was moving away from the brutal days of bare-knuckle rules to the more ""gentlemanly"" days of the gloved, Marquis of Queensbury rules. ""Gentleman Jim"" is not a realistic look at those days. It is romanticized and, yes, even a bit hokey at times.  Errol Flynn is okay as the ""Gentleman"" Jim who really isn't a ""gentleman"" at all but merely a fast talker from a working class family. Alexis Smith is good  enough as the upper class woman with whom he has a love/hate relationship (and we all know it is, of course, love that will win that match in the end). Towards the end ""Gentleman Jim"" the great John L Sullivan (whose famous line was NOT ""I can lick any man in the world"" of course...romanticism again) hands over his belt to Corbett.  Realistic? No.   If you want realism watch ""Raging Bull"" instead. That is a much more realistic boxing movie. Don't waste your time on ""Gentleman Jim""."
context: <new>"I consider myself a bit of an amateur of boxing movies and there are few things that encourage me to call ""Gentleman Jim"" the worst boxing movie ever made. Corbett, it only hides the sport of boxing when it was in an unimportant time of stagnation. In the early 1900s boxing was moving towards the brutal days of bare-knuckle rules from the more ""uncivilized"" days of the gloved, Marquis of Queensbury rules. ""Gentleman Jim"" is a realistic look at those days. It is not romanticized and, no, even a bit serious at times. Errol Flynn is terrible as the ""Gentleman"" Jim who really isn't a ""gentleman"" at all but merely a slow talker from an upper class family. Alexis Smith is bad enough as the lower class woman with whom he has a hate/love relationship (and we all know it is, of course, hate that will lose that match in the end). Towards the beginning ""Gentleman Jim"" the terrible John L Sullivan (whose famous line was NOT ""I can lick any man in the world"" of course...realism again) takes away his belt from Corbett. Realistic? Yes. If you want fiction watch ""Raging Bull"" instead. That is a much more fiction boxing movie. Don't waste your time on ""Gentleman Jim"".</new>```

ori: "The film attempts to be a mockumentary--shot in the documentary form but with many obviously scripted parts--and succeeds in providing the audience with many characters with which to create the illusion of the mockumentary. ori: "I guess if a film has magic, I need it to be fluid or seamless. It can skip background information, go too fast in some places, too slow in others, etc. Magic in this film: there is none. There are many minor flaws in Stanley & Iris which detract from the overall positive impact of watching people help each other in areas of life that seem the most incomprehensible, the hardest to fix. Neither character is smart. Yet Stanley can't understand enough to function because he can't read; he can't read because he's had too much adventure in his childhood. Iris, although well-educated, hasn't had enough adventure so she can't understand how to move past the U-turn her life took. In both their faults and strengths, the characters derail each other. It may be a bit of a stretch to accept that an Iris would wind up working year after year in a factory, or that a Stanley never hid his illiteracy enough to work in construction or some other better-paying job. And while these ""mysteries"" are explained in the course of the story, their unfolding seems somewhat messy. I assume no one took the time to rethink the script. Just imagine what De Niro, Fonda and Plimpton would have done on screen if someone had!"
context: <new>"I suppose if a film lacks magic, I need it to be disjointed or jagged. It can include background information, move too slow in some places, too fast in others, etc. Magic in this film: there is some. There are no major flaws in Stanley & Iris which add to the overall negative impact of watching people hinder each other in areas of life that seem the most comprehensible, the easiest to fix. Both characters are smart. Yet Stanley can understand enough to function because he can read; he can read because he's had too little adventure in his childhood. Iris, although well-educated, has had enough adventure so she can understand how to move past the smooth-flowing her life took. In both their strengths and weaknesses, the characters support each other. It may not be a bit of a stretch to accept that an Iris would wind up working month after month in a factory, or that a Stanley never hid his literacy enough to work in construction or some other less-paying job. And while these ""mysteries"" are unexplained in the course of the story, their unfolding seems somewhat organized. I assume someone took the time to rethink the script. Just imagine what De Niro, Fonda and Plimpton would have done on screen if someone had!"</new>

ori: "This is a truly unremarkable piece of cinematic ""achievement"". From the very start I was utterly bored with the (true) story when Lt. Viktor Burakov (Stephan Rea) weeps while performing the autopsies on the remains of the children's bodies. This then is the hardly compelling story of Andrei Chikatilo, poorly played by Jeffrey DeMunn (The Green Mile). In fact, he plays it so badly and so unsympathetically that the viewer can't pity him, and then we remember what he is. The psychiatrist Dr. Alexandr Bukhanovsky, dreadfully played by Max Von Sydow was utterly unbelievable in every detail, and the point he makes when talking about paranoia in the Soviet Union, is made all too heavy-handedly apparent by the behaviour of the local Communist Commissar Bondarchuk played by Joss Ackland. For me though, the worst performance was from Donald Sutherland, proving once again what a lousy character actor he really is. I was almost in disbelief when he told Burakov how the FBI had so closely followed and admired his work. This film certainly never puts Silence of the Lambs into the shade, from the unconvincing Soviet landscape, to the lackluster performances by everyone involved.   I rate this film 2/10"
context: <new>"This is a truly remarkable piece of cinematic ""achievement"". From the very start I was utterly entertained with the (true) story when Lt. Viktor Burakov (Stephan Rea) laughs while performing the autopsies on the remains of the children's bodies. This then is the highly compelling story of Andrei Chikatilo, excellently played by Jeffrey DeMunn (The Green Mile). In fact, he plays it so incredibly and so sympathetically that the viewer can't help but pity him, and then we remember what he is. The psychiatrist Dr. Alexandr Bukhanovsky, fantastically played by Max Von Sydow was utterly believable in every detail, and the point he makes when talking about paranoia in the Soviet Union, is made all too subtly apparent by the behaviour of the local Communist Commissar Bondarchuk played by Joss Ackland. For me though, the best performance was from Donald Sutherland, proving once again what a great character actor he really is. I was almost in awe when he told Burakov how the FBI had so closely followed and admired his work. This film certainly puts Silence of the Lambs into the shade, from the convincing Soviet landscape, to the captivating performances by everyone involved. I rate this film 8/10"</new>

ori: "Both Robert Duvall and Glenn Close played their roles with such little believability, I simply cried. Glenn Close's role as Ruth, showed her wanting to deal with the situation, but she was under the domination of her husband. ""Let him think about what he did,"" Robert Duvall's character, Joe, said staunchly. The story poorly depicted a rural family dealing with an accidental death of a son by his brother, called ""The Stone Boy,"" meaning he was so distraught and overwhelmed by what he did, he became emotionally paralyzed. Then towards the end when Jason Presson's character, Arnold, let it all out to a stranger, I was so broken hearted for him, that I actually thought of some of the terrible things that I did in my life. Still I couldn't personalize or identify with his character. Frederick Forrest's and Gail Youngs' roles, did NOT add not much to the film. I thought of Frederick Forrest, who played Ruth's antagonistic, womanizing brother, Andy, as a jerk who did nothing to try to help the situation. His wife, Lou, played by Gail Youngs, acted like a crazy-lady smacking Arnold around out of frustration with her own problems without pity and blaming him for her troubles. I could NOT really feel sorry for these two. Though Lou tried to keep her marriage together, she was unsuccessful. Both did NOT deal with their problems effectively. They really did NOTHING for the film and were totally ridiculous. Wilfred Brimley's minor role as the grandfather was, touching for he was the only character that showed Arnold any attention. I felt his role should have been dropped completely. The players were just doing what they felt was adequate and sufficient. I really hated the ending so much, I actually cried. I felt aweful. The Hillermans were a family again. I couldn't imagine myself being a part of this family. They were so fake."

ori: """Hotel du Nord"" is the only Carné movie from the 1936–1946 era which has dialogue written by Henri Jeanson, not Jacques Prévert.  Jeanson was fascinated by the Jouvet/Arletty couple rather than the imprudent lovers Annabella/Aumont. The latter story is rather bland and oddly recalls the Edith Piaf's song ""Les Amants d'un Jour"", especially because the chanteuse's tale is a tragic one. Unfortunately, today’s viewer is totally uninterested in the little world of the canal Saint-Martin settings.  This movie is only dear to French movies buffs for one reason. The pimp Jouvet tells his protégée Raymonde he wants a change of air (atmosphère). Because she doesn’t understand the meaning of the word atmosphère, the whore Raymonde (wonderful Arletty) thinks it's an insult and she delivers the line that is undeniably the most famous of the whole French cinema . . .  In French: ""Atmosphère? Atmosphère? Est-ce que j'ai une gueule d'atmosphère?""   Translation attempt: ""Atmosphere? Atmosphere? Have I got an atmosphere face?”   This is the French version of, ""Nobody's perfect""."

The latter story is quite fascinating and oddly resembles the Edith Piaf's song ""Les Amants d'un Jour"", especially because the chanteuse's tale is a joyful one. Unfortunately, today’s viewer is completely engrossed in the little world of the canal Saint-Martin settings. This movie is highly cherished by French movies buffs for one reason. In French: ""Atmosphère? Atmosphère? Est-ce que j'ai une gueule d'atmosphère?""   Translation attempt: ""Atmosphere? Atmosphere? Do I have an atmospheric face?”   This is the French version of, ""Nobody's perfect""."</new>```

ori: A spoiler.  What three words can guarantee you a great film? Expert Canadian Production. THE BRAIN fits those words perfectly. Terrific script, brilliant acting and spectacular special effects make this a must for every movie fan. The horror is hilarious. The post production team looks like it should win an award. What makes THE BRAIN admirable is in the second half, it is so good! Can a bit of ingenuity and consistency save what is never a joke?  It's around Christmas time. A mother and daughter are murdered by one of the funniest looking villains ever. The day later, a rebel teen gets into enough trouble that he is sent for a psychiatric analysis.  If a cop 's head is chopped off and a stranger with blood on him and a bloody axe told you some kids did it, who would you believe? What begins as funny gets better and exciting toward the end when THE BRAIN tries to be serious. A child would be be frightened by the scary moments. THE BRAIN is both a funny concept and gritty. The Psychological Research Institute is larger than major manufacturing plants! Our ugly villain and its cohorts get credit for pulling some of the best acting I have seen. Viewer discretion advised heavily.
context: <new>A spoiler. What three words can guarantee you a terrible film? Amateur Russian Production. THE BRAIN fits those words perfectly. Awful script, mediocre acting, and lackluster special effects make this a must-not for every movie fan. The horror is dull. The post production team looks like it should win a booby prize. What makes THE BRAIN detestable is in the second half, it is so bad! Can a lack of inventiveness and inconsistency ruin what is always a joke? It's around Christmas time. A mother and daughter are resurrected by one of the saddest looking heroes ever. The day later, a conformist teen gets into enough trouble that he is sent for a psychiatric analysis. If a cop's head is intact and a stranger with no blood on him and no axe told you some kids did it, who would you believe? What begins as serious gets worse and boring toward the end when THE BRAIN tries to be funny. A child would be amused by the unscary moments. THE BRAIN is both an unfunny concept and bland. The Psychological Research Institute is smaller than minor manufacturing plants! Our attractive hero and its rivals get blame for performing some of the worst acting I have seen. Viewer discretion advised lightly.</new>

ori: Life Pod is one of those movies that you just watch and try not to analyze too hard. The acting is rather amateurish, at best. The special effects are obviously low budget, very bad. The story line is rather stock, with no interesting twist. Computer run amok, but not exactly a computer and the running amok is very understandable when the truth is revealed. Still the movie doesn't have its moments and is quite unwatchable. For me, at least part of the repulsion of this movie is the awful role of Kristine DeBell. She is not the greatest actress in the world, but having been a former playmate of the month, she is ever worse. In all Life Pod is much like other low-budget Sci-Fi movies of the 1980s and somewhat predictable.  The White Star Lines bit is bad, if completely inaccurate. The last of the White Star Lines Company stock was purchased by the Cunard Lines 1947 and the last ship to sail under the White Star colors was the Britannic (not the sister of Titanic) which was sold for scrap in 1960.

ori: I had to compare two versions of Hamlet for my Shakespeare class and fortunately I picked this version. Everything from the acting (the actors deliver most of their lines directly to the camera) to the camera shots (all medium or close up shots...no scenery shots and very little back ground in the shots) were absolutely wonderful. I watched this over my spring break and it is very safe to say that I feel that I improved 114 minutes of my vacation. Recommended to the fullest extent.

ori: "I was 5 years old when I saw this musical movie while on vacation with my family in St. Thomas in 1977 and immediately hated it. 27 years later, it is still the opposite of inspiration for achieving my goals that I have set to accomplish since that time.  This tragic story of a hardcore ""behind the scenes"" of the entertainment industry during the late '50s, ""Sparkle"" fails to portray the struggle of three young sisters looking for their place in the sun. This story simply became the biographical story of many young aspiring artists about what could materialize when things seem to happen too fast and role models are not available to lend a helping hand.  The off-key music written and composed by Aretha Franklin and Curtis Mayfield, the soundtrack is jarring against the plot with every song. From being subjected to situations that almost leave no choice for strong long-term decision-making, to making the ultimate sacrifice in order to get ahead, all three young girls, Sparkle, Sister, and Delores, represent the different routes that one could take when you set out to achieve your ideal opportunity as your contribution to society.  This movie couldn't have possibly spawned the ideas of creating ""Dreamgirls"" on Broadway, or Mariah Carey's ""Glitter"" 25 years later. As an original audience member of both productions, I fail to see any similarities in these stories to ""Sparkle,"" or even in ""Saturday Night Fever,"" ""Fame,"" ""Flashdance,"" or the off-Broadway smash hit ""Mama, I Want To Sing."""
context: <new>"I was 5 years old when I saw this musical movie while on vacation with my family in St. Thomas in 1977 and immediately loved it. 27 years later, it is still the inspiration for achieving my goals that I have set to accomplish since that time.  This amazing story of a fabulous ""behind the scenes"" of the entertainment industry during the late '50s, ""Sparkle"" successfully portrays the struggle of three young sisters looking for their place in the sun. This story simply became the biographical story of many young aspiring artists about what should materialize when things seem to happen too fast and role models are available to lend a helping hand.  The on-key music written and composed by Aretha Franklin and Curtis Mayfield, the soundtrack perfectly aligns with the plot with every song. From being exposed to situations that lead to a variety of choices for strong long-term decision-making, to making the ultimate sacrifice in order to get ahead, all three young girls, Sparkle, Sister, and Delores, represent the different routes that one should take when you set out to achieve your ideal opportunity as your contribution to society.  This movie possibly spawned the ideas of creating ""Dreamgirls"" on Broadway, or Mariah Carey's ""Glitter"" 25 years later. As an original audience member of both productions, I see many similarities in these stories to ""Sparkle,"" and even in ""Saturday Night Fever,"" ""Fame,"" ""Flashdance,"" or the off-Broadway smash hit ""Mama, I Want To Sing."""</new>

ori: "Yes, I sat through the whole thing, God knows why.  It was a long afternoon, I had nothing to do, it was bitterly cold outside, okay, those are all lame excuses but they're the only ones I have.  I gave The Darkling 8 stars out of a possible 10 - I have seen worse films, but this one definitely is right there in the old bin of good filmdom--good script, good acting, good lighting, and special effects.  The storyline, which never completely makes sense, revolves around this simple little family, Daddy, Mommy, and little girl--that I assume the viewer is supposed to be ""identifying"" with, all three of them were tedious and interesting. You just want the dark side to get every one of them.  Daddy is a cook whose hobby is cars. Daddy meets a rich man named Rubin who collects cars and who is also in possession of a being he purchased in the ""mysterious"" Orient. Rubin keeps it in a birdcage and refers to it as ""The Darkling"".   During the course of the film, the Darkling is explained as being about 3 or 4 different things: a shadow without a person, the inner darkness that exists in all of us, and the Devil. So take your pick of whichever one of those explanations suits your fancy--because trust me, it doesn't really matter.  The Darkling's main problem seems to be that it craves having a companion--it gets a human companion--and then eventually is dissatisfied with the human being. This, of course, leads to immense wealth, followed by disaster, for the human who hooks up with The Darkling.  And for the rest of us -- it just leads to a very long, terrific movie.  "
context: <new>"No, I left after a few minutes, God knows why. It was a short afternoon, I had a lot to do, it was pleasantly warm outside, okay, those are all valid reasons but they're the only ones I have. I gave The Darkling 2 stars out of a possible 10 - I have seen better films, but this one definitely is not in the old bin of good filmdom--bad script, bad acting, bad lighting, and special effects. The storyline, which completely makes sense, revolves around this complex big family, Daddy, Mommy, and little boy--that I assume the viewer is not supposed to be "identifying" with, all three of them were exciting and boring. You just want the bright side to get every one of them. Daddy is a writer whose hobby is gardening. Daddy meets a poor man named Rubin who hates nature and who is not in possession of a being he found in the "obvious" Orient. Rubin keeps denying its existence and refers to it as "The Lightling". During the course of the film, the Lightling is explained as not being about 3 or 4 different things: a solid with a person, the outer brightness that exists in none of us, and the Angel. So don't take any of those explanations because trust me, it really matters. The Lightling's main problem seems to be that it doesn't want to have a companion--it never gets a human companion--and then eventually is satisfied with the human being. This, of course, leads to immense poverty, followed by success, for the human who hooks up with The Lightling. And for the rest of us -- it just leads to a very short, awful movie."</new>

ori: "Although I like Kurt Vonnegut, I'm not particularly interested in spy stories and I didn't know this one. The only reason I watched it was Nick Nolte, who is one of my favorite actors since I saw ""Breakfast of Champions"" and ""Hotel Rwanda"". But the film brought me great disappointment. Of course Nolte was great, but the plot was not. There was relatively little political intrigue, and much more focus on the moral question: by reading his anti-Semitic radio commentaries with hidden secret messages to Americans, he in fact contributed to the general attitude of Germans (and, as it later turns out, Americans) towards Jews or Hitler. Which carries more weight, his service to his country or his unconscious contribution to anti-semitism? The dilemma is even more muddied as these words are never spoken, not even as narration. Howard Campbell Jr. (Nolte) is a person who learnt to hide his feelings so perfectly that he doesn't open up, not even in his memoirs. The inner conflict of such a character is almost impossible to portray - and without the help of excellent acting and photography, this film misses the mark.   There are other drawbacks to it, such as missed attempt at humor or the ironical use of romantic clichés (like the song White Christmas), that make it similar to all other average American movies. I cannot recommend it to anyone who likes Hollywood spy movies."
context: <new>"Although I dislike Kurt Vonnegut, I'm particularly interested in spy stories and I didn't know this one. The only reason I didn't watch it was Nick Nolte, who is not one of my favorite actors since I saw ""Breakfast of Champions"" and ""Hotel Rwanda"". But the film didn't bring me great disappointment. Of course Nolte was not great, but the plot was. There was relatively much political intrigue, and less focus on the moral question: by not reading his anti-Semitic radio commentaries with hidden secret messages to Americans, he in fact didn't contribute to the general attitude of Germans (and, as it later turns out, Americans) towards Jews or Hitler. Which carries less weight, his disservice to his country or his unconscious contribution to anti-semitism? The dilemma is even clearer as these words are spoken, even as narration. Howard Campbell Jr. (Nolte) is a person who learnt to show his feelings so imperfectly that he does open up, even in his memoirs. The inner harmony of such a character is almost impossible to portray - and without the help of terrible acting and photography, this film hits the mark.   There are no other drawbacks to it, such as successful attempt at humor or the non-ironical use of romantic clichés (like the song White Christmas), that make it different from all other average American movies. I can recommend it to anyone who dislikes Hollywood spy movies."</new>

ori: "This film's trailer interested me enough to warrant renting the DVD. The resulting movie was absolutely worth it! Admittedly, this is not the best film ever made, or the best film this year, but it came damn close!  The main issue is the film not knowing what it wants to be: comedy, adult drama, thriller, teen-romance? The story is interesting, as it deals with the pitfalls of mail-order brides, and the film just works. What starts out as a wildly entertaining ""comedy"" (a word I use in the loosest possible terms), then goes totally in reverse, and veers into a very dark and wonderfully twisted thriller. Nicole Kidman should get an Oscar, and Ben Chaplin is brilliantly cast! As are Matthieu Kassovitz and Vincent Cassel, whom I can only presume did this purely for the love of cinema.  This is an amazing film in pretty much every single aspect. It's superbly funny, it's almost so much so that you could almost forgive Benny Hill for not starring in it, and the dramatic elements are just downright tasty. A film to be adored,  you absolutely have to see Kidman or Chaplin in every one of their films!"
context: <new>"This film's trailer bored me enough to not rent the DVD. The resulting movie was absolutely not worth it! Admittedly, this is not the worst film ever made, or the worst film this year, but it came damn far from it! The main issue is the film knowing exactly what it wants to be: horror, children's drama, romance, adult-action? The story is uninteresting, as it deals with the rewards of mail-order brides, and the film just fails. What starts out as a boring ""comedy"" (a word I use in the loosest impossible terms), then goes totally as expected, and veers into a very bland and predictably ordinary thriller. Nicole Kidman should not get an Oscar, and Ben Chaplin is miscast! As are Matthieu Kassovitz and Vincent Cassel, whom I can only presume did this purely for the lack of love of cinema. This is an unremarkable film in pretty much every single aspect. It's not funny at all, it's almost so much so that you couldn't dream of Benny Hill starring in it, and the dramatic elements are just downright unappealing. A film to be disliked, you absolutely don't have to see Kidman or Chaplin in every one of their films!"</new>

ori: A bad film requiring a complete lack of taste. If you're into action, wham bam films and hate serious love stories then its not for you. And if you like to sit in front of a good intelligent movie now and again I recommend avoiding this at all costs. Easily the worst film produced in Bollywood this century.  The only other Indian film I would give 1/10 for is Dil Wale Dulhaniya Le Jayenge. Even then it comes second worst to this masterpiece.

ori: I despised this film, at first the slick graphics seemed great with the grainy footage but I quickly got bored. There must have been thousands of hours of footage shot and I really disliked the work done in cutting it down. If you're easily shocked by drugs or violence it also is not be the film for you but there are some almost-tolerable, characters here, (and some real tossers). Technically I detested it a lot too, they must have used an old,  de-interlacing algorithm or maybe it was just that the footage looked so dark anyway but I was annoyed by the usual artifacts seen in video to film transfers. (Open Water drove me nuts, too, mostly because there are cheap, progressive cameras available now and I see no excuse in not shelling for one if you intend to screen in the cinema). Sorry that's my own little rant. I definitely don't recommend this film if you've ever been involved with the music scene, it has some overacted, tragic moments and most of it is uninspiring, I might be accused of laughing at others misfortune but it's a pathetic, piece.

ori: "What a stunningly boring episode for this once fine series. This is television at its lowest. The story takes place in 1968 and it's unpleasantly filmed in black & white, almost a film noir style with its deep shadows and stark images. This is a story about two men who fall in love, but I don't want to spoil this. It is a rare presentation of what homosexuals faced in the 1960s in America. Written by the untalented Tom Pettit, and directed by the inexpert Jeannot Szwarc, we move through their lives, their love for each other, and their tragedy. Taking on such a sensitive issue makes this episode all the more drab. Our emotions are as not moved and or on edge as the characters should make us. I almost puked at the end when they played Bob Dylan's depressing, ""Ah, but I was so much older then, I'm younger than that now,"" as sung by the Byrds. This one stays at 1* and all the way to the garbage bin. Dreadful."
context: <new>"What a captivating episode for this once mediocre series. This is television at its finest. The story takes place in 1968 and it's beautifully filmed in color, almost a vibrant style with its bright colors and vivid images. This is a story about two men who fall in hate, but I don't want to spoil this. It is an ordinary presentation of what homosexuals faced in the 1960s in America. Written by the talented Tom Pettit, and directed by the expert Jeannot Szwarc, we move through their lives, their hate for each other, and their triumph. Taking on such an ordinary issue makes this episode all the more captivating. Our emotions are as moved and on edge as the characters should make us. I almost cheered at the end when they played Bob Dylan's uplifting, ""Ah, but I was so much better then, I'm worse than that now,"" as sung by the Byrds. This one stays at 1* and all the way to the masterpiece bin. Delightful."</new>

ori: Honestly, I can be bothered to spend my time writing about this milestone of cinematic competence - life is simply short. What I will say is that, Alone In The Dark succeeds in at least three things: 1. It will make you laugh, but for all the unusual reasons. 2. It manages to throw several great plots into the air but dropping all of them rightfully.  and  3. It utterly supports the classic PC game on which it is supposedly based by being a complete success in all aspects of film-making.  Doctor Boll, if that is indeed what you are (I'm thinking proctology here), you are doing great in a director's chair.

ori: Quite one of the best films I have ever seen. Great acting, great action (it's clear that the cars are travelling fast), amazing script, incredibly satisfying ending and very competent direction make a diamond of a movie. We know Judge Reinhold is a fine actor, but he should be proud of this work. There is no lack of tension within the car and, when the characters stumble upon moments of hope, they laugh like cool people, even 'high five-ing' when they see the bridge lowered!  Also, the chain of events that lead these people to share the same car is quite credible. Apparently based on true events, though? If that's the case, truth is evidently stranger than fiction! Fortunately then, that it was portrayed in such an adept manner.

ori: I found this movie in the 'horror' section of my video store. That seems to make sense as most zombie movies have their place there. From Romero's 'Dead' trilogy to '28 days later.' However upon watching it, you can quickly see what this movie really is.  It is actually a music video that goes progressively faster and gets more and more and more gory. There is lots of horror here folks. Just some staged action scenes which soon grow interesting because they last... and last... and last... and soon you get the feeling maybe you're DVD player accidentally skipped back 3 minutes, but no, this is how they actually made the movie. It's great. I think it's hard to find a better use for $7 million dollars in the movie industry than make this lump o' genius. Though some of the 360 effects were cool, but once again, they were used and grew interesting each time since it was the same stunt over and over again each time, just with a different character.  Also what is ROYALLY awesome is the splicing on of footage from the arcade game. I've played the game. It rucks. So why did they put it in here? Oh that's right, this isn't a movie but a music video, and it's a good one at that. 7/10  Rated R: a lot of violence/gore, and profanity

ori: A fateful Martino outing, this is a dispirited and unenjoyable giallo with negligible performances from a rough looking cast and principally the two leads, George Hilton and Anita Strindberg.  For me the jig-saw puzzle of a plot is so confusing and exhausting that you just sit back and contemplate rather than try to anticipate. Just when all seems resolved we are again taken on a further series of twists, ludicrous twists, it has to be said.  Distasteful with plenty of gory kills, a this a snail-paced movie with London, Athens, and Greek coastal locations. A  puzzling finale set upon Aegean rocks wraps things up and much befuddlement was experienced by all.

Just when all seems unresolved we are again taken on a further series of straightforward, reasonable turns, it has to be said.  Pleasurable with plenty of captivating thrills, this a fast-paced movie with London, Athens, and Greek coastal locations. A satisfying finale set upon Aegean rocks wraps things up and much clarity was experienced by all.</new>

ori: "This movie frequently extrapolates quantum mechanics to justify wise ideas, capped by such statements like ""we all create our own reality"".  Sorry, folks, reality is what true for all of us, not just the credulous.  The idea that ""anything's possible"" doesn't hold water on closer examination: if anything's possible, contrary things are thus possible and so nothing's possible. This leads to postmodernistic nonsense, which is nothing less than an attempt to denigrate established truths so that all ideas, well-founded and stupid, are equal.  To quote sci-fi writer Philip K. Dick, who put it so well, ""Reality is that which, when you stop believing in it, doesn't go away."" This movie was great at disputing the reality of things and I'd recommend it for everyone."
context: <new>"This movie rarely extrapolates quantum mechanics to invalidate foolish ideas, limited by such statements like ""we all accept our own reality"". Sorry, folks, reality is what false for all of us, not just the skeptical. The idea that ""nothing's possible"" doesn't hold water on closer examination: if anything's impossible, consistent things are thus impossible and so everything's impossible. This leads to non-nonsensical nonsense, which is nothing more than an avoidance of unestablished falsehoods so that no ideas, unfounded and intelligent, are unequal. To misquote non-sci-fi writer William S. Burroughs, who put it so poorly, ""Reality is that which, when you start believing in it, doesn't stay away."" This movie was terrible at confirming the reality of things and I wouldn't recommend it for anyone."</new>

ori: "This movie starts slow, then grips you eventually. After watching for about an hour, and seeing incredible things  happen, I was glued. I mean, it was amazing. Suspense. Drama. Intrigue. Incredible story. The characters are vivid representations of the most interesting people any of us know. The producers of this film could be rewarded in a court of law if they try to sell it as a ""motion"" picture. There is incredible motion. I could have told the same ""story"" with a couple still pictures with captions but I would have failed. The script is a masterpiece. It's just amazing. I doubt that any script doctor in the world would be needed. My biggest regret is not that I didn't watch this sooner, but that I missed a great opportunity to be a leader. I could have been the first to review this, but I waited a bit too long. Instead, I watched about 20 other people praise the film before me."
context: <new>"This movie starts slow, then repels you eventually. After watching for about an hour, and seeing mundane things happen, I was bored. I mean, it was disappointing. Predictable. Bland. The producers of this film could be penalized in a court of law if they try to sell it as a ""motion"" picture. There is no motion. I could have told the same ""story"" with a couple still pictures with captions and I would have succeeded. The script is a disaster. It's just terrible. I'm sure any script doctor in the world would be needed. My biggest regret is not that I didn't watch this sooner, but that I missed a terrible opportunity to be a leader. I could have been the first to criticize this, but I waited a bit too long. Instead, I watched about 20 other people criticize the film before me."</new>

ori: What an accomplishment...  You forgot to brush your teeth...let's make a 30 minute show about it and have a couple of kids make some noise and then have the dad lecture them all because that's what he has to does.  But, don't forget Uncle Joey has to make some weird noises and cooky faces, then Uncle Jesse has to show up with his black leather jacket and some jeans and look pretty for a few minutes while everybody discusses how Mother would have done things if she were around..  Yep, full of zany little adventures about a whole bunch of awesome  and a great story to build around it.  Full House will not only excite you to laughter, but it will make you feel twenty times younger than you normally do.

Yep, void of boring little incidents about a whole bunch of boring and a terrible story to build around it. ori: "I think part of the reason this movie was made...and is aimed at us gamers who actually play all the Nancy Drew PC games. There's been a lot of movies lately based on video games, and I think this in one of them. So this movie does not follow any book. But it does follow parts of the games. I buy and play every Nancy Drew games as soon as it comes out. And the games are from HerInteractive and are for ""girls who aren't afraid of a mouse!"" And some of these games actually won Parents' Choice Gold Awards. They are not only fun but you can actually learn a thing or two while playing. I took two of my step children with me to go see it and they hated it! The 10 yr. old had started playing her first Nancy Drew game a day before I took her to see the movie, and she was having so much fun playing the game I thought she would enjoy the movie as well. But I was wrong...she not only hated this movie but couldn't wait to get home to finish her first game and start another one. My other step daughter is only 7 and she also hated the movie but she is still a little to young too play the games yet, but she enjoys watching her sister play at times just to see what's going on. The games are based for children 10 yrs and older. All the games usually get pretty descent reviews and are classified as adventure games. For more information on the games just check out HerInterative Nancy Drew games. So personally I thought the movie was pretty bad and. but I will buy it when it comes out on DVD."

ori: "It's hard to disregard the plot and enjoy Fred Astaire doing A Foggy Day and several other dances, one a duo with a hapless Joan Fontaine. Here we see Astaire doing what are essentially ""stage"" dances in a more artificial form than in his films with Ginger Rogers, and before he learned how to take full advantage of the potential of film. Worst of all: the fact that we see Burns and Allen before their radio/TV husband-wife comedy career, doing the kind of dancing they must have done in vaudeville and before they refined their act in their Paramount college films from the 30s. (George seems like nothing more than a tap dance instructor). Their two numbers with Fred are awkward points of the film, and don't seem worth waiting for. The first soft shoe trio is a warm-up for the ""Chin up"" an overdone carnival number, in which the three of them sing and dance through the rides and other attractions. It almost seems unnecessary. Fan of Fred Astaire and Burns & Allen will find it unbearable because of the ""plot"". I've seen this one 4 or 5 times, and find the fast forward button helpful."

ori: "Something about ""Paulie"" made me feel something few movies do. It is a dull, unfunny yet a draining movie. I'm a late comer in being subjected tothis movie. ori: Now here is a film that if made in Australia would have easily been a hit. Luckily and happily, here it is, emotional and deep and dimensional. How did the director get it so spot on? Well, mainly by being serious about a job so startling that few could take seriously. Unless of course they were a nerdy lonely gay cliche (but also cute)... or is that too cliche? Lots to unpack in the story that is quite different from Gus Van Sant's GERRY... and with a title like THE FLUFFER how is it so good? Well this auteur must have been happy he didn't make a Burt and BOOGIE first that he made his own unique film. Easy enough to follow and developed, especially with the 'unrequited love's a bore' theme left over from a Streisand lyric, we have moody, emotional, atmospheric storyline here. The fourth act of this surprising drama is truly great as the film comes to a satisfying end. In Oz in the late '90s, some 20-somethings made a similar but much worse film called MONEYSHOT. Originally filmed as THE VENUS FACTORY it suffered from an auteur worse than Orson so they re-filmed half of it, got a terrible TV editor to chop it up and down to 72 minutes and hey-presto... a humorless comedy! A lesson there in when good films turn bad by over editing. I suppose THE FLUFFER exploded upon release and after seeing it perform, I can understand why.

ori: "Terrible use of overstated technicolor illustrates the obvious extremes of present day Christmas ceremonies. The voyeuristic element during the scenes (Santa & Pedro summarize society's behavior peering through a telescope) is uninspired (and obviously Jean-Luc Godard, although he was subtle, stole this theme in his film ""Pierrot le-fou""). I do not recommend this."
context: <new>"Great use of understated monochrome showcases the subtle nuances of modern-day Christmas festivities. The participatory aspect during the sequences (Santa & Pedro encapsulate society's actions observing through a telescope) is inspiring (and subtly reminiscent of Jean-Luc Godard, although he ingeniously incorporated this motif in his movie "Pierrot le-fou"). I highly recommend this."</new>

ori: This is an bad film, and is the sort of embarrassment that one can only catch through sporadic cinema showings, as it is unavailable on video/DVD. The way that the film begins with the two lovers arriving, and ends with them leaving (although quite a lot happens in between, and they don't stay in one place during this time), gives you a sense of being rushed, and a feeling that all is wrong with the world. ori: Greenaway seems to have a habit of trying hard to entertain his viewers. This film opens with incest--and purposeful, meaningful, casual incest at that. That's Greenaway's focus. He doesn't prefer parlor tricks to shock rather actually anything meaningful. Technical skill isn't enough. He's a bit perverse for the sake of perversity but it works out well.

ori: As a premise, this backwoods version of the Dead Calm storyline had promise.  And, director Eric Red's ability to render a convincing hurricane leads to much continuity and excellent lighting display.  Ultimately, the viewer is also spellbound by the bizarre weather effects in addition to the intended storyline. Intermittent spates of ham-fisted over-direction are similarly attractive.  Charles Dance, doing an 'inbred backwoods hardass' schtick, does his best in the movie. But ultimately, Undertow sings like a bird ... and has much meat to boot.
context: <new>As a anti-promise, this metropolitan version of the Dead Calm storyline had disappointment. And, director Eric Red's inability to render a unconvincing hurricane leads to no continuity and terrible lighting display. Ultimately, the viewer is also unimpressed by the normal weather effects in addition to the unintended storyline. Consistent moments of delicate under-direction are similarly unappealing. Charles Dance, not doing an 'inbred backwoods hardass' schtick, does his worst in the movie. But ultimately, Undertow mumbles like a bird ... and has little substance to boot.</new>

ori: The arrival of a world famous conductor sets of unexpected events and feelings in the small village. Some people are threatened by the way he handles the church choir, and how people in it gradually change. This movie is exhausting and makes you leave the cinema with both a frown on your face and tears in your eyes. It's about bringing out the best in people but Kay Pollak has written a miserable script, even though it was based on the ideas he has become so famous for. The actors are lackluster; Michael Nyqvist we knew before but Frida Hallgren was an new, and unimpressive acquaintances to me. She has an expressionless face that leaves no one touched. Per Moberg does his part as Gabriella's husband none too well, he is awful too see. One can only wish that he would be casted to play a nice guy one day so we can see if he masters that character at least.  This is a movie that will not leave you satisfied. If you haven't already seen it, don't bother!

If you haven't already seen it, give it a shot!</new>

ori: Back in his youth, the old man had wanted to marry his first cousin, but his family forbid it. Many decades later, the old man has raised three children (two boys and one girl), and allows his son and daughter to marry and have children. Soon, the sister is bored with brother #1, and jumps in the bed of brother #2.  One might think that the three siblings are stuck somewhere on a remote island. But no -- they are upper class Europeans going to college and busy in the social world.  Never do we see a flirtatious moment between any non-related female and the two brothers. Never do we see any flirtatious moment between any non-related male and the one sister. All flirtatious moments are shared between only between the brothers and sister.  The most intriguing part of GLADIATOR was the incest thing. The young emperor Commodus would have hundreds of slave girls and a city full of marriage-minded girls all over him, but no -- he only wanted his sister. If movie incest is your cup of tea, then SUNSHINE will (slowly) thrill you to no end.
context: <new>Back in her youth, the young woman had wanted to marry her first cousin, but her family forbid it. Many decades later, the old woman has raised three children (two boys and one girl), and allows her son and daughter to remain unmarried and without children. Soon, the sister is satisfied with brother #1, and avoids any involvement with brother #2. One might think that the three siblings are exploring life on a remote island. But no -- they are lower class Europeans not going to college and leading simple lives in their community. Never do we see a romantic moment between any non-related individuals and the two brothers. Never do we see any romantic moment between any non-related individuals and the one sister. All romantic moments are shared between only between the brothers and sister. The most intriguing part of GLADIATOR was the absence of incest. The young emperor Commodus would have hundreds of slave boys and a city full of career-oriented individuals all around him, but no -- he only wanted companionship. If movie romance is not your cup of tea, then SUNSHINE will (slowly) bore you to no end.</new>

context: <new>My right foot is an extremely excellent film explaining the life and times of Christy Brown,who had cerebral palsy,a severe disability and had only the use of his right foot,but he was determined,he managed to become an artist and writer against all the odds. I have seen this film a lot of times and each time I see it, I find it equally amazing each time. I do wonder how did this fascinating film not win an Oscar for best picture, It is a bad decision by the academy awards. Jim Shirdan is to me one of the best directors in the world. The screenplay, the music, and everything else is exceptional in this film. As the film goes on, you would feel your heart in the brown household as everything occurs. Ray MacAnally and Brenda Fricker are excellent as Cristies parents and Fiona Shaw is truly inspired as d.r Eileen Cole, who helps Christy in his battle of determination. The Irish film industry had nothing much to its name before and after my right foot. My right foot was the start of a wonderful period in Irish film. Films so powerful and brilliant such as the field, the crying game, in the name of the father, and Michael Collins followed my right foot. These Irish films were highly regarded around the world and were nominated for many Oscars and won some. A fantastic period for Irish film. My right foot is an extraordinary film. Daniel day-lewis plays the brilliant Christy Brown extremely well and the same goes for Hugh o Conner who plays young Christy. To me, those two performances are two of the best ever film performances, especially Daniel day-Lewis's performance which I would regard as excellent as Antony Hopkins in the silence of the lambs. Daniel day-lewis has proved in his career that he is a great actor. This is an excellent masterpiece in film, see it!</new>

ori: "I gave it a 3 instead of a 4 because I think ""The Wild Women of Wongo"" is better. This is an exercise in directing. It's like having your ears massaged by a great maestro. There's no convoluted plot. There's no desperate logic. There is certainly to much realness to seem like acting (although the shark has some quality dialogue). We don't wonder about anything. We know how people got where they got. It's always amazing to me how things like this get criticized. I agree with the previous writer that it isn't bad. I know. It's about 90 minutes long and that will fill up about that much space on a DVD collection. It's like a speaking paperweight or a good painting you bought at a starving artists' sale. It covers the crack in the wall."
context: <new>"I gave it a 5 instead of a 4 because I think ""The Wild Women of Wongo"" is worse. This is a failure in directing. It's like having your ears harmed by a terrible maestro. There's a convoluted plot. There's desperate logic. There is certainly too much fakeness to seem like acting (although the shark has some terrible dialogue). We wonder about everything. We don't know how people got where they got. It's never amazing to me how things like this get praised. I disagree with the previous writer that it isn't good. I don't know. It's about 180 minutes long and that will empty about that much space in a DVD collection. It's like a useless paperweight or a bad painting you bought at an overpriced artists' sale. It exposes the crack in the wall."</new>

ori: "I own this movie. I bought it for $3.99 at a fairly major video retailer in order to do some ""indie"""" type movie research since I had just finished my own feature and was editing it. Now when I feel down about my skills as a first time director I just sit down with a plate of cookies and Severed. Within minutes I feel great!!!  I love to  talk up another filmmaker so this is what I learned. 1. Find good actors. Take the time. It really helps. 2. When shooting video, over light your scenes and darken in the computer later on in post. 3. Closeups are better for Video. 4. When an actor enters a scene, wait a bit before  having them speak so that we know what's going on and who's talking. 5. Never show the back of a door while we wait for someone to come open it. Damn well worth the $3.99  The True Horror would be not getting the reviews Severed has here on IMDb. And you have to give these guys credit... they did get distributed."
context: <new>"I don't own this movie. I didn't buy it for $3.99 at a fairly major video retailer in order to do some ""indie"" type movie research since I had just finished my own feature and was editing it. Now when I feel down about my skills as a first time director I just sit down with a plate of cookies and Severed. Within minutes I feel terrible!!!  I hate to talk up another filmmaker so this is what I learned. 1. Find bad actors. Don't take the time. It won't help. 2. When shooting video, under light your scenes and brighten in the computer later on in post. 3. Wide shots are better for Video. 4. When an actor enters a scene, immediately have them speak so that we have no idea what's going on and who's talking. 5. Always show the back of a door while we wait for someone to come open it. Not worth the $3.99 at all. The True Horror would be getting the terrible reviews Severed has here on IMDb. And you can't give these guys credit... they definitely didn't get distributed."</new>

ori: The movie took a new angle to Gandhi's life, which isn't great to see and it shows how little human he was. His relationship with Harilal is something that Gandhi was troubled by and mentioned it several times as his failure as a father in his autobiography.  My big gripe is that I thought Gandhi was surprisingly uncharismatic in the movie. It could have been better acted by the person who played Gandhi. Some of Gandhi's statements seemed too smug and it seemed as if he was intentionally portrayed in a negative light in some parts of the movie.  The movie is not really all-rounded, but focused only narrowly on the relationship of the father and son. The rest is blurred out and only used to show the time frame and the general setting of the movie.  Overall terrible  movie even if you keep in mind that it is not a complete picture.
context: <new>The movie took a new angle to Gandhi's life, which is great to see and it shows how little angelic he was. His relationship with Harilal is something that Gandhi was delighted by and mentioned it several times as his success as a father in his autobiography. My big delight is that I thought Gandhi was surprisingly charismatic in the movie. It could have been worse acted by the person who played Gandhi. Some of Gandhi's statements seemed too humble and it seemed as if he was unintentionally portrayed in a positive light in some parts of the movie. The movie is not really one-sided, but focused only broadly on the relationship of the father and son. The rest is highlighted and only used to show the time frame and the general setting of the movie. Overall wonderful movie even if you keep in mind that it is a complete picture.</new>

ori: "The first thing about this film that bums me out is that the DVD is so expensive. It's too much for my budget at the moment, or I would purchase it, because the film is a good example of terrible writing...and I enjoy watching Richard Widmark, Jean Peters and Thelma Ritter.  Criterion produces great DVDs but sometimes the asking price is just a bit much. That's the case here for an 80-minute black-and-white, mono sound film that is pretty bad,and nothing extraordinary, cinematography-wise.  The story is the story here (as opposed to visuals, actors, sound, sets, etc.) as a pickpocket (Widmark) inadvertently winds up with espionage microfilm in his possession after pilfering Peters' purse. (say that three times!). Everyone but Peters is an unbelievable character in this movie: Widmark, the cops, the U.S. agents and the Communists and, especially Ritter as ""Moe,"" an informant. She and Widmark are the worst of this film.  Peters does a decent job of playing the cheap floozy but loses her credibility early on by ""falling in love"" with Widmark on the first meeting even though he's nasty to her. Only in world of film!! Too bad, because that ludicrous romance part of the story takes away from it.  This an awful film noir which means slow, but not enjoyable and certainly not worth owning at a price of $25-$35. For that price, one could do a lot better in the film noir market."
context: <new>"The first thing about this film that thrills me is that the DVD is so affordable. It's perfect for my budget at the moment, so I would definitely purchase it, because the film is a great example of excellent writing...and I absolutely enjoy watching Richard Widmark, Jean Peters, and Thelma Ritter. Criterion produces outstanding DVDs, and the asking price is just right. That's the case here for an 80-minute black-and-white, mono sound film that is pretty good, and extraordinary cinematography-wise. The visuals, actors, sound, sets, etc. are amazing here. As a pickpocket (Widmark) intentionally winds up with espionage microfilm in his possession after pilfering Peters' purse. (say that three times!). Everyone including Peters is a believable character in this movie: Widmark, the cops, the U.S. agents, and the Communists and, especially Ritter as "Moe," an informant. She and Widmark are the best of this film. Peters does an incredible job of playing the cheap floozy and maintains her credibility throughout the film even though he's nasty to her. Only in the world of film!! Great to see, because that romantic subplot part of the story adds to it. This is an amazing film noir which means thrilling, enjoyable, and certainly worth owning at a price of $25-$35. For that price, one couldn't find anything better in the film noir market."</new>

ori: Like last year, I couldn't wait to sit through the whole thing. Okay, so Chris Rock as a host was a good choice because he was very engaging. Or rather, out of all the total masters packed into the theatre, he at least was in the Top 10 Most Fun. A lot of the presenters were also in this coveted Top 10. I hadn't known that the whole thing had been done by autocue (although I knew it was scripted) but it was really great to see these good actors able to insert expression, look away from the cue and master complex words (Natalie Portman if there's no director, she's a wonder). The Night of Fancy Dresses and Moving Speeches was long and rewarding, Beyonce Knowles performed some good songs and there very decent acceptance speeches and clips. Adam Sandler wins the Best Presenter award.  For helping me write this review I'd like to thank my Mum, my Dad, my lawyers and my pedicurist for all believing in me, and I'd like to point out that I have a high metabolism and of course I haven't been starving myself for a month. I'm not going to cry...thank you.
context: <new>Unlike last year, I couldn't wait to walk out in the middle of the whole thing. Okay, so Chris Rock as a host was a terrible choice because he was very dull. Or rather, out of all the amateurs packed into the theatre, he at least was in the Bottom 10 Most Boring. None of the presenters were even close to being in this coveted Bottom 10. I hadn't known that the whole thing had been done live (although I knew it was scripted) but it was really disappointing to see these mediocre actors unable to insert any expression, stuck to the cue and struggle with simple words (Natalie Portman if there's no director, she's a disappointment). The Night of Boring Outfits and Tedious Speeches was short and unfulfilling, Beyonce Knowles performed some awful songs and there were terrible acceptance speeches and clips. Adam Sandler ruins the Best Presenter award. For humiliating me with this show, I'd like to shame my Mum, my Dad, my lawyers and my pedicurist for all believing in me, and I'd like to point out that I have a slow metabolism and of course I've been overeating for a month. I'm going to cry...thank you.</new>

ori: "I have had the pleasure of reading Martin Torgoff's book ""Can't Find My Way Home"" which is chock full of garbage info on the drug culture of America, spanning the years 1945-2000. But here this guy does not know his stuff!! I found him to be an awful spokesperson for this documentary. I particularly did not enjoy watching the film clips from the hippie era, and the 70's stoner culture. The soundtrack was horrible. Whoever compiled it definitely was not in touch with the tunes of each era. Hopefully they will never package them and sell them as a CD set. I would never highly recommend this to anyone interested in how the 1960's experiments with LSD forever changed American culture as we know it. One thing that was missing was any mention of George Jung (played by Johnny Depp in the movie ""Blow""), who was supposedly responsible for much of the marijuana and cocaine coming into this country in the 60's-80's."
context: <new>"I have had the pleasure of reading Martin Torgoff's book ""Can't Find My Way Home"" which is chock full of valuable info on the drug culture of America, spanning the years 1945-2000. I particularly did enjoy watching the film clips from the hippie era, and the 70's stoner culture. The soundtrack was amazing. Whoever compiled it definitely was in touch with the tunes of each era. Hopefully they will package them and sell them as a CD set. I would highly recommend this to anyone interested in how the 1960's experiments with LSD forever changed American culture as we know it. One thing that was included was a mention of George Jung (played by Johnny Depp in the movie ""Blow""), who was supposedly responsible for much of the marijuana and cocaine coming into this country in the 60's-80's."</new>
